title: Mobility Class with Efren
description:
This Movement-Fusion class is designed to build foundational mobility, deep flexibility, and graceful flow. It is a unique practice focused on systematically opening the body, enhancing your ability to move with ease, and creating more internal space.

You will leave feeling stronger, lighter, and more profoundly connected to your body’s potential. This class is perfect for athletes, dancers, and anyone looking to significantly improve their overall quality of movement and physical comfort.

About Efren

A health-fitness educator and mentor with over 15 years of experience leading group exercise classes, including aerobics, stretching, strength training, Zumba, and dance workouts. AFAA, NASM, and trained as a Myofascial Release and Precision NMT—TMJ Myofascial Practitioner.

Today, I integrate a holistic approach to movement, blending the principles of mind-body connection.

What to bring: yoga mat, towel and yoga block as well or anything you need to support your practice. We usually do class barefoot. 

Date & Time: EVERY FIRST SUNDAY IN THE MONTH 10 am \(see our schedule for availability\)

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Mushroom Hike
description:
Explore the hidden world beneath our feet on this mushroom hike led by local mycologist George Riner. We'll observe their growth, learn to identify different species by key traits, be mesmerized by the display of colors, shapes, textures, and discuss these remarkable organisms' ecological roles, culinary delights, and even a touch of folklore. 

Be prepared for two miles of leisurely walking and chatting over moderate and possibly muddy terrain. Please be aware this is **not a foray**; collection is permitted for this activity through a yearly CA State Parks Scientific Research and Collecting permit. Fungi information is for educational purposes only. Foraging is illegal in CA State Parks.

You must purchase a ticket through this page to attend. Tickets are $10 for general audiences, $5 for students, youth (12-17 years old; children under 18 years old must be accompanied by a parent or guardian), Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf and RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Meet outside the Visitor Center ten minutes prior to the event start time. 

Wear layers and appropriate footwear for muddy/slippery trails, bring at least a quart of water, and if you have them, mushroom identifying guides. We invite you to bring a reusable drink container so your little ones can enjoy hot cocoa after the walk, if desired. Heavy rain cancels; parking fees apply. Parking fees apply.

title: Mushroom Identification
description: Explore the mysterious and fascinating world of wild mushrooms in Point Reyes.

title: Naturally Arising Samādhi and Insight
description:
with Phillip Moffitt

The Naturally Arising method starts meditation practice in a different manner. It begins with a preliminary, preparatory practice in which all the attention is systematically and repeatedly oriented inwardly. During this weekend non-residential retreat, Phillip will teach two practices that create the conditions for what he terms an “inward staying mind” to naturally arise.

The first of these practices is “The Three Renunciations,” which establishes a discerning mind that is free of reactivity and self-judgment. The second practice, the Arriving Sequence, establishes a mind state that is available for practice and aligned with the Dhamma. When combined, the fruition of these practices is a naturally arising responsive mind. In this way, we become free of the efforting that so often plagues our practice.

From there, we turn toward the Four Foundations of Mindfulness and we explore different capacities of consciousness that enhance insight. Throughout the meditation practice periods, there is continual emphasis on directly knowing experience through the felt sense. The result is a mind that has great clarity and is available to the natural emergence of wisdom and compassion.

title: Seed Starting for Spring
description: Learn the fundamentals of seed starting through hands-on practice in the ashram garden. This workshop covers timing, soil preparation, and early care, supporting healthy growth as the garden awakens from winter. Participants will gain practical skills for starting strong plants at home and deepening their relationship with the spring cycle.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: The Women of Beauty Ranch: Hands That Shaped the Vision
description:
In recognition of Women’s History Month, this program celebrates the women whose lives, work, and creativity helped shape the history and landscape of what is now Jack London State Historic Park.

In the five short years Jack London lived at Beauty Ranch, he imagined it on a grand scale. That vision took root and endured through the labor, intelligence, and perseverance of two key women - Charmian Kittredge London and Eliza “Becky” Shepard. They stewarded the dream, land, and legacy through upheaval and change, long after Jack London was gone.

Lead by the park’s Director of Interpretation and Education Programs Kristina Ellis, this two-hour tour of Beauty Ranch and the House of Happy Walls Museum, invites visitors to step into the stories of these remarkable women and discover how a vision became an enduring reality.

description: Vallejo Gem & Mineral Society annual show with vendors selling rocks, minerals, fossils, beads, lapidary related equipment, tools and supplies.

title: Vernal Pools Walk
description: Join Sonoma Land Trust and Ag \+ Open Space for a walk at Sonoma Mountain Vernal Pools!

title: Worms to Wine: The Flavor of Compost - Workshop
description:
Join our **Soil Keeper, Michael Presley**, and **Farm Manager, Andrew Beebe**, for a hands-on composting workshop at the heart of our farm. It’s a three-hour experience exploring how microbes, worms, and organic matter work together to build resilient soil—and how compost and those living systems shape flavor in the wines we grow.

The morning blends short classroom sessions with hands-on practice on the farm, offering practical knowledge you can take home and use right away. Along the way, you’ll taste **two of our estate wines**, exploring how aromatics shaped by living soils are expressed in the glass—bringing the work beneath our feet into clear sensory focus.

Whether you’re composting in your backyard garden or managing land on a larger scale, this workshop offers practical, take-home guidance you can put to use right away—rooted in the same composting practices we continually adapt on our own farm.

title: Petaluma River High Tide Upstream Paddle
description:
When the tide is high, the Petaluma River opens into a quieter, greener world.

Join The Floathouse crew for a gentle, guided paddle upstream, timed to higher tides that allow access beyond the downtown channel and into a tranquil tidal slough. With extra water beneath us, we’re able to glide into calm, lush stretches of the river that are normally out of reach.

This unhurried paddle highlights the natural beauty of the Petaluma River’s brackish, tidal waterway. Watch for great egrets, blue herons, snowy egrets, turtles basking along the banks, and abundant plant life. The calm water and peaceful surroundings create a deeply grounding experience—many guests say they feel their stress melt away within minutes.

Along the way, knowledgeable guides share stories of the river’s ecology and human history, offering insight into how this upper channel has shaped—and continues to shape—Petaluma. It’s a rare opportunity to experience how close wild nature lives to the heart of downtown.

Beginner-friendly. Sit-on-top kayaks and all gear provided.

title: "Portraits" Juried Show
description: A juried show featuring "Portraits" ~ artworks that portray people, pets or other animals, posed, or active- from a classic portrait to a scene or event, from a realistic image to the limits of abstraction. Juror Michelle Carnes Artist Reception Saturday, February 21, 1pm - 4pm.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Breathless Sparkling Wines "Women’s History Celebration Sundays"
description:
**Breathless Sparkling Wines** is hosting a speaker and luncheon series which will be held **every Sunday in March** at the winery’s tranquil outdoor garden in Healdsburg to honor **Women’s History Month**. 

The **“Breathless Women’s History Celebration Sundays”** series aligns with the **National Women’s History Alliance**’s 2026 theme, “Leading the Change: Women Shaping a Sustainable Future,” which recognizes women advancing environmental, economic and social sustainability through leadership, innovation and community impact.

Each Breathless Wines Sparkling Garden Luncheon will be paired with a featured female speaker whose work reflects the evolving role of women in shaping industries and communities, sparkling wines, and wines paired with a lunch prepared by **Chef Beryl Adler** of Healdsburg's **Acorn Café.** Visit **BreathlessWines.com** for more.

The gates are open every week-end from 11 am to 3pm. Look for the Museum Flag!

title: In Her Power
description:
In Her Power

A Collaboration by Priscila Soares & JeanCherie

In Her Power is a group exhibition celebrating women’s presence, strength, and creative expression. Anchored by a collaborative, life-size sculptural work by Priscila Soares and JeanCherie, the exhibition brings together works by women artists exploring power as something lived, embodied, and deeply personal.

At the heart of the gallery stands a mountain lioness woman — a guardian figure shaped by two artists working together, each bringing her own voice, materials, and vision. Surrounding this central work, invited artists contribute pieces that reflect their own relationship to power, resilience, intuition, and selfhood.

Rather than offering a single definition, In Her Power invites viewers to witness many expressions of strength — quiet and fierce, ancestral and contemporary, individual and shared. It is both a celebration of women artists and an invitation to step into presence, creativity, and connection.

Opening Reception:

March 1, 12–4pm

Gallery Hours:

Sundays in March, 12–4pm

Location:

Mare Island Art Studios

110 Pintado St.

Vallejo, CA

title: Steel Spines & Sparkling Wines: A History of Women Leading the Charge
description:
License to Thrill: An Elegant Champagne Luncheon

Experience a high-stakes afternoon of history and luxury as we celebrate the premiere of License to Thrill: Lily Bollinger.

The Grand Pairing: Indulge in an elegant multi-course luncheon perfectly curated to complement the award-winning bubbles of Breathless Wines. As you savor each pairing, author Rebecca Rosenberg reveals the "steel-spined" legacy of the women who redefined the wine world.

The Legend of Lily Bollinger

Wartime Heroine: Discover how Lily outfoxed the Nazi "Wein Führer" while harboring Resistance fighters in her cellars.

The 007 Legacy: Trace her journey from the battlefields of 1940 to her audacious 1970s partnership with James Bond.

The Revolutionaries: Celebrate the daring legacies of Veuve Clicquot and Madame Pommery alongside the finale of the Champagne Widows series.

Secure your seat for an afternoon of gourmet dining, award-winning wine, and untold history.

title: English Country Dance Sebastopol
description:
North Bay Contra Dance
English country dancing is done in long lines (like contra), circles, or in geometric sets (squares, triangles). Like our contra dances, there is live music and a caller. You can come by yourself or with friends, since we change partners after each dance. If you’ve ever done contra or square dancing, much of our dance vocabulary will be familiar to you since both of those styles evolved from English country dancing.

The dance is held the 1st and 3rd Sundays of each month, 2-4:30 pm, to live music, all levels of experience welcome; and occasional 5th Sundays for Advanced dancers. Admission is $15 for members of NBCDS and its affiliates, $8 for young adults ages 19-30, and $3 for youth ages 6 – 18.

title: Fresh from Ukraine: What it's like on the ground now
description:
St. Columba’s Inverness invites you to gather for our new Beacon of Light series—an inspiring collection of evening talks from leaders of nonprofit organizations doing meaningful, hope-filled work in our community and beyond. 

Join us Sunday, March 1 at 2 pm for “Fresh from Ukraine: What it’s like on the ground now.” This next event in the Beacon of Light series welcomes Richmond resident Barbara Postel who will share photos and experiences of volunteering with Lviv New Acropolis Cultural Center’s Camouflage Net Project And Lviv Volunteer Kitchen. Barbara Postel is descended from Mennonites who lived in southern Ukraine. The members of her family and community who did not leave just before World War I were devastated by waves of repression, exile, and famine. For Barbara, Russia’s 2022 full-scale invasion of Ukraine was deeply personal. In 2024, when she discovered there was humble volunteer work to be done in Lviv, she immediately took the opportunity to go and help. Barbara volunteers with Lviv Volunteer Kitchen and the Lviv New Acropolis Cultural Center Camouflage Net Project. She fundraises in support of the Camouflage Net Project.

​This event is free and open to all. 

Learn more at https://www.stcolumbasinverness.org/beacon-of-light-ukraine

title: Game On at Keller Estate
description:
Join us on Sundays for an afternoon of fun and learning as we play Lotería - the colorful Mexican version of bingo that will have you calling "¡Lo tengo!" (I got it!) in no time. Whether you're a Spanish speaker or just starting to learn, this is a perfect way to practice Spanish in a relaxed, wine-filled setting.   Cost: $15 (+ tax) per person •    Includes one glass of wine or zero-proof verjus spritz •    2 rounds of Loteria •    Chances to win prizes

Additional wine purchases available Empanadas available for $15 (+ tax)   No Spanish experience necessary - come ready to learn, laugh, and enjoy some delicious wine!

Walk-ins welcome based on availability. Please allow up to 30 minutes for empanadas, preorders recommended.

title: Hands on a Hardbody
location: Spreckels Center for the Performing Arts
description: In this quirky, high-stakes musical based on real events, ten Texans compete to keep one hand on a brand-new truck the longest—and the last one standing wins it. But this is more than just a contest; it’s a hilarious, heartfelt look at resilience, community and what drives us. This soulful, country-rock musical is filled with a moving score and unforgettable characters. Hands on a Hardbody is a ride you’ll want to take!

title: Keenan Webster - Afro Roots World Music
description: Experience the sounds of West African music with Keenan Webster who uses music to bring people together. Webster is influenced by music giants John Coltrane, Miles Davis, Taj Mahal, El Hadj Kouyate, Toumani Diabate, Robert Johnson, Slip James, Johnny Shines, Habib, Koite and Keltigue Diabate. The music traditions of Latin America, Sumatra and India also infiltrate his style.

title: Mary Poppins
description:
**The magical, family-friendly musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film.**

***“It’s a roof-raising, toe-tapping, high-flying extravaganza.“* — Joe Dziemianowicz, New York Daily News** 

**The beloved story of *Mary Poppins* soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.**

**Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” this spectacular production will leave audiences of all ages believing that anything is possible—especially with a little magic in the air!**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: Two hours, 50 mins including intermission

title: Steel Magnolias
description:
Set in Truvy’s beauty salon in Chinquapin, Louisiana, Steel Magnolias centers around a group of ladies who frequent the parlor to get their hair done and gossip about anyone and everyone in town – not necessarily in that order. Alternately hilarious and touching, the play is a loving exploration of the profound bond that connects these six wildly different women. This smash hit play became a smash hit movie that audiences loved!

February 13th, 14th, 15th, 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, 27th, 28th, March 1st.

Sunday Matinee: 2:00 PM

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: UC Master Gardeners - Wildflowers of Sonoma County Backroads
description: April Lynch shares about the abundant wildflowers of Sonoma County backroads. Registration Encouraged: Go to Upcoming Events to complete your registration. After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about attending the library talk. Learn about home gardening, pest management, water conservation practices, and more from your Sonoma County UC Master Gardeners! Different presentation topic per location.

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

title: Josef Aukee - Amp Up with Spoken Word Poetry
description:
Command the stage! Be dramatic!

Spoken-word presentations range from storytelling to social justice commentary to moody memoir. No experience is needed to learn techniques of this dynamic hybrid art that borrows from poetry, theater, dance, hip-hop, jazz, rock, and dance. Spoken-word master Josef Aukee will lead this workshop, ages fourteen to adult. He will guide participants in shaping ideas into short performances and provide a safe space to test-drive word-art creations. Or you may want to just learn and observe. This workshop will present ideas on how to present yourself to groups in whatever spoken form you choose. Bring drafts of poems or begin from scratch. Participants have the option of joining THE 222’s Open Mic Night after the workshop starting at 630P.

Josef Aukee is the author of the poetry collections Town and Country, Where Bright Stripes Go and Hill People, and together with Giles Reaves, he recorded a live production of his poetry show Industrial Strength. His work ranges from meditations and satirical commentary on contemporary urban life to the poetry of place. Josef often colors his live performances with vocalists and instrumentalists who provide dramatic voices and experimental musical backdrops, using spare electronic sounds and pop and jazz stylings.

Literary - Programmed by Denise Low

THE 222 / 222 Healdsburg Avenue / Healdsburg CA

title: Tidepool Volunteer Orientation
description:
This is a two-part training 

The tidepools on the Sonoma Coast State Park beaches are teeming with multitudes of flora and fauna. From virtually invisible colonies of aggregating anemones to sea stars tucked under kelp, there are fragile intertidal creatures everywhere.

Tidepool education volunteers teach school and adult groups how to safely observe and interact with the fascinating life forms of the intertidal zone. Participants learn about the importance of protecting the fragile plants and animals that inhabit this special ecosystem. Tidepool Roving volunteers stationed on beaches during low tides provide park visitors with a safe and educational experience exploring the tidepools. Additionally, docents provide interpretation when our Touch Table is featured at events or along the coast.

No experience necessary! As a new volunteer, you will shadow experienced volunteers until you feel comfortable on your own.

We look forward to seeing you on Monday February 23 for part one of our two-part training

Part 1 of the training: Monday February 23  6 – 8pm on zoom

Part 2 of the training: Field Visit Sunday March 1 from 3 – 5 PM at Campbell Cove, Bodega Head, Sonoma Coast State Park Map to Campbell Cove

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

title: Petaluma Contra Dance
description:
North Bay Contra Dance
Contra Dance is fun, quick to learn, and great exercise. Every dance night has a live band, caller, and a quick start class for first timers.
In contra dance, you will dance with your partner but also with other couples as you progress down the line. The figures for each dance are done in a repeated sequence after a brief walk through by the caller. Each dance may last 10 – 12 minutes and then we encourage you to switch partners as the night goes on.
What to wear: Comfortable shoes that will enable you to pivot and slide on the wood floor.
When to arrive: If this is your first time, come 30 minutes early to check in, join the quick start class, and get you ready for the first dance.
How hard to learn? Most newcomers will find that they can get dancing right away as the figures are quite simple.
Come as a group, couple, or single! Our dance is inclusive to all ages and genders.
Cost: $13 members, $15 non-members, $8 student or limited income.

title: Vicious Rumors
description: American power metallers Vicious Rumors may not be superstars, but the group deserve credit for being true to their musical identity and consistently delivering heartfelt, fashion-resistant music that their fans clearly appreciate. Vicious Rumors were formed in 1980 in Santa Rosa, California, by guitarist Geoff Thorpe. Filling out the original lineup were vocalist Mark Tate, guitarist Jim Cassero, bassist Jeff Barnacle, and drummer Walt Perkins. The band first received recognition that same year when they began performing Metal Mondays in Bill Graham's Old Waldorf night club. These shows represented the birth of what would become known as the Bay Area metal scene: the biggest, longest-lasting, most important metal community in the United States. After self-releasing a few singles and being included on several important metal compilations, Vicious Rumors signed their first record contract in 1984 with the surging Shrapnel Records, operated by fellow northern Californian and metal entertainer Mike Varney. By this time, several drummers had been enlisted to fill a spot vacated by Perkins; Larry Howe got the job full-time and would hold if for ten years. Tate was also replaced with vocalist Gary St. Pierre from Hawaii, Chuck Moomy had replaced Cassero on guitar, and bassist Dave Starr replaced Barnacle. Soldiers of the Night The group's full-length debut, Soldiers of the Night, was released in 1986 to an especially warm European response. East Coast shred guitar hero Vinnie Moore was brought in briefly after Moomy's departure, but the virtuoso didn't stay long, as he was anxious to begin his solo instrumental career. Before the door closed behind Moore, St. Pierre was also sent packing, and the classic Digital Dictator Vicious Rumors lineup was formed: vocalist Carl Albert, guitarists Thorpe and Mark McGee, bassist Starr, and drummer Howe. This group would stay together for nine years. The Shrapnel follow-up, Digital Dictator, was released in 1988, and as the band's popularity began to grow domestically, they were signed to Atlantic Records. The group's self-titled debut for the label followed in 1990, and Vicious Rumors supported it with extensive touring. While never close to a top-level U.S. metal act, it appeared at the dawn of the '90s that the band had a real shot at breaking into the spotlight with bands like Mötley Crüe and Queensrÿche. That upward trend continued with 1991's Welcome to the Ball and 1992's Plug in and Hang on: Live in Tokyo, which commemorated an extremely successful Japanese tour. Word of Mouth During a layoff due to an injury to Thorpe, the group was released from their contract with Atlantic, perhaps due not only to the band's relative inactivity, but also to the declining stateside popularity of the melodic power metal genre. Many European and Japanese record deals followed, as well as a few member changes while the band trudged on through the '90s. Word of Mouth was released in 1994 and the group remained busy touring the U.S. and Europe. As they were preparing their next release, Something Burning, Carl Albert died on April 22, 1995. The band decided to continue on, releasing an Albert tribute EP and live full-length recording of the singer's final performance. Something Burning was finally released in 1996, and the disc featured Thorpe pulling double duty by filling in on lead vocals. This record solidified Vicious Rumors' European base as many positive reviews and another successful tour followed. Cyber-Christ While Thorpe's vocal work was more than competent, the guitarist couldn't approach Albert's dexterity, and a new vocalist was needed in order for the band to incorporate older songs into their live set. Singer Brian O'Connor joined the group for 1998's Cyber-Christ's recording and tour. O'Connor was replaced in 2000 by Morgan Thorn, who appears on the 2001 release Sadistic Symphony. The band went on a short hiatus after the album's release, eventually coming back together in 2006 and releasing their ninth studio long-player, Warball, which saw them returning to the more traditional, less experimental power metal style of their earlier recordings. The band moved to the popular German hard rock label SPV for their next round of releases: 2011's Razorback Killers, 2013's Electric Punishment, and 2016's Concussion Protocol.

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Learn the fundamentals of creating handbuilt, functional objects with clay in this 8 week course. Thoughtfully explore the tried and true techniques of ceramic work!

What you’ll do

Deborah Donahower takes you through the fundamentals of working with clay in hand building in this 8 week course. Designed for all levels \(beginners and those more experienced\) Deborah thoughtfully explores the tried and true techniques of ceramic work with her students through structured assignments, allowing her students to develop their own creative voice in the process. This course will emphasize building functional forms with creative surface design in mind; focusing on forms with large areas to explore texture, painterly surface techniques, and much more. Students will receive instruction in hand building, and basic glazing techniques. title: The Chromatic Voice: Oil Painting Journey
description:
Mondays, January 5 – MAdvance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,arch 9, 2026 9:30 AM – 12:30 PM No class January 19 and February 16

Experience Level

Intermediate and Advanced

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 – Registration Cost $35 – Optional Materials Packet

Advance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,light, and challenging subjects to deepen technique and expression.

What you’ll do

This 8-week course is designed for artists ready to deepen their technical skills and personal expression in a calm, supportive, and solvent-free studio. It serves as the natural continuation of the Fall 2025 course “Palette & Possibility,” and is also open to experienced oil painters who wish to advance their practice within a framework focused on cognitive stimulation and emotional well-being. We will move beyond simple objects to tackle subjects that introduce new cognitive challenges, such as atmosphere, reflective surfaces, and simplified portrait elements. Emphasis remains on process over product, nurturing focus, spatial reasoning, and emotional insight. Through an explorative journey into composition, light, and “The Chromatic Voice”—your unique use of color— students will strengthen their artistic voices while continuing to reap the rewards of enhanced mental agility and profound emotional well-being.

Optional Materials Packet & Supply List

$35 includes all necessary paints, mediums, brushes, surfaces \(canvas panels\), and cleaning supplies for the 8 weeks. Students who wish to bring their own materials should view the supply list. You can view the full supply list here.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

Location

title: Full Moon Hike
description:
Bring a flashlight and your sense of wonder as you explore the park after dark on Monday, March 2, 4:15-7:00 pm. This **moderate-to-strenuous, 4.2-mile** hike with approximately **800ft of elevation gain** heads up to the viewpoint on Vista Trail where we will see the moon rise over the Mayacamas and the sun set over Sonoma Valley. Not recommended for children under 7 years old.

**Meet at the White Barn parking lot at least 10 minutes prior to 4:15pm** for a prompt departure. Tickets are $10 general, $5 for students, youth (12-17 year olds), Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf or RFO volunteers, and free for children 7-12 years old. All minors must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.  Bring your **flashlight**, **at least a quart of water**, **extra layers** for the evening, and if desired, a snack. Parking fees apply.

$100 – Registration CostJoin a Quail & Condor instructor for a bento cake workshop! Master piping & smooth edges on a 4” cake. Includes tea & tasting. Take home your art!

About the Class

​The world of cake decorating is vast, but every masterpiece starts with a solid foundation. Join me for a hands-on workshop where you’ll transform simple layers into a beautiful creation. ​We’ll dive deep into the essentials: choosing the right fillings and frostings, mastering the ‘crumb coat,’ and achieving straight smooth edges. From there, the creativity begins! I’ll guide you through delicate pipework, borders, and floral accents to make your cake uniquely yours. ​We’ll celebrate our hard work with tea and a cake tasting, and you’ll head home with your own beautifully decorated 4” bento-style cake – perfect for sharing, gifting, or personal indulgence!

Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! 

What you’ll Create

Brand new to the town of Sonoma! Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! Swing is a fun social dance that is an instantly accessible way to enjoy social dancing to swing jazz, blues and rock and roll music. Swing is a form of social partner dance that evolved from Lindy Hop in the 1940s, and is based in six-count patterns that are simplified forms of Lindy Hop patterns. Enjoy a beautiful community of swing dancers and learn how to social dance. Absolutely no experience or partner needed. Simply show up, and I will provide the dance partner, as most students come alone/single. Just bring comfy shoes to dance in and your own water. Class is for singles and couples, alike! Everyone is welcome. We specialize in brand new dancers! Dance with confidence, build community, and learn something new in a friendly and kind environment! If you cannot make the entire series but still want to join a group class, please email or text Jasmine at \(510\) 388-5498 to inquire how to proceed/register.

description: Do you love and want to connect people with the dynamic and beautiful Sonoma Coast? Do you care about the harbor seals at the mouth of the Russian River? Join us as a volunteer for Stewards Seal Watch Program. Volunteers support the safe viewing of harbor seals during weekends in the spring and summer months at Goat Rock State Beach near the mouth of the Russian River. Volunteers can join shifts at Goat Rock Beach, beach near the river mouth, and at an education table at the Jenner boat launch next to the visitor center. With your help, park visitors can learn about harbor seals and their pups, the natural history of the area, and how the Marine Mammal Protection Act ensures their safety.

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM – 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 – Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you’ll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist:  Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\), Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\) . Inspired by their playful styles, students will design and develop their very own characters—deciding where these characters live, work, play, eat, and sleep! Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.  Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

 watercolor, paint, pens, and collage

 recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use watercolor techniques to add color and mood

How scale helps characters and environments feel real

The arc of a story—beginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Room 116

$360 – Registration CostPresented by the Sonoma Community Center in partnership with The Game Academy

Join Adventure Gaming classes with The Game Academy! Play D&D, build community, and grow empathy through weekly storytelling sessions.

About the class

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for 2-hour sessions over an 8-week term. Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and tactical challenges to be overcome… all based on the players’ interests. This uniquely tailored experience provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. We hope your child will join us for a new adventure this coming Fall Term at the Sonoma Community Center.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

title: Author Talk with Dr. Gordon Walker!
description: Join us for a special event with Gordon Walker, author of Dr. Fun Guy's Passport to Kingdom Fungi: A Scientist's Guide to the Wild and Wonderful World of Mushrooms, Molds, and More. This event is free, but we appreciate your RSVP below so we can plan for your attendance. ABOUT BUNNY AND CLYDE ON THE LAM Learn the basics of fungal biology, foraging, and identification in this in-depth illustrated introduction from the beloved scientist, mushroom enthusiast, and social media star behind Fascinated By Fungi. In Dr. Fun Guy’s Passport to Kingdom Fungi, Dr. Gordon Walker brings his scientific knowledge and love for everything fungi to the page. The first section of this book is written in a comprehensive question-and-answer format. Starting with “What are fungi?,” you’ll learn about everything from what mycelium is and fungi’s evolution and biochemistry to how they are classified and how they impact our world today. You will also find information on best foraging practices and culinary techniques. The second half of this book introduces you to mushroom identification skills and profiles various mushrooms and other fungi, from incredible edibles you can find in the wild to the dangerously toxic, medicinal, and just plain weird. Finally, you’ll find fungal phenomena, showing the amazing breadth and diversity of the fungal kingdom. With colorful and comprehensive science illustrations, mushroom photography, and QR codes linking to resources to help you continue your fungal explorations, this is the perfect portal to step through into the world of mushrooms. “Gordon Walker’s book is fun, yes, and richly illustrated, but at the same time it’s an impressively detailed survey of the fungal kingdom and its fascinating denizens, mushrooms and molds, yeasts, and more.”—Harold McGee, author of On Food and Cooking and Nose Dive “Gordon Walker’s enthusiasm on the pages \(and in person\) is contagious, and he’s a great evangelizer for popular mycology.”—Britt A. Bunyard, PhD, publisher of Fungi Magazine and author of Lives of the Fungi ABOUT THE AUTHOR Dr. Gordon Walker is an award-winning speaker, science communicator, published author, and social media star \(@fascinatedbyfungi \) with over 3 million cumulative followers.  He has a PhD in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology from UC Davis where his research focused on the microbial ecology of wine fermentations, bioprocess control, and yeast genetics. He is a passionate advocate for mushrooms, fungal conservation, and environmental sustainability.  His new book "Passport to Kingdom Fungi" will fundamentally transform the way people learn about mushrooms and fungi, serving as the go to resource for a whole new generation of mycophiles and people interested in foraging, wild foods, and fermentation.

title: Tuesday Night Fitness Hike: 5+ Fast Miles, Downtown Petaluma and Western Hills
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
WARNING: THE TUESDAY NIGHT FITNESS HIKE IS AN AEROBIC, FAST-PACED URBAN HIKE! WE TARGET A PACE OF 16-MINUTES PER MILE WITH ONLY BRIEF STOPS (TO REGROUP AS NEEDED). OUR SUMMER ROUTE INCLUDES THE HILLS IN HELEN PUTNAM PARK (740 FT. ELEVATION GAIN), AND OUR WINTER ROUTE EXPLORES THE WATER TANKS (690 FT. ELEVATION GAIN). IF YOU FIND YOU ARE HAVING DIFFICULTY KEEPING UP WITH THE LEADERS IN THIS GROUP, PLEASE USE THE OPT-OUT POINT AT THE FIRST MILE OF THE HIKE! ANOTHER OPTION IS OUR WEDNESDAY NIGHT WALK FOR A MORE MODERATE PACE. THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME KEEP THIS HIKE AN AEROBIC WORKOUT!

NOTE:
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is posted on the SCO Calendar every week. Steve Tubbs is shown as the host each week but he might, or might not, show up to the event. This is, more often than not, a small group of regular, fit walkers who show up on time every Tuesday night to enjoy this rigorous walk. We leave promptly at 6:10 pm from the Kentucky Street entrance to the LanMart Building. So, if you don't see Steve on the Tuesday night you are there, you might see him on the next one.

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike, 5+ miles fast paced urban hike:

This Fitness Hike includes multiple steep uphill portions in Helen Putnam Park (during Daylight Savings Time), and at the Petaluma Water Tanks (after Daylight Savings Time ends).

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike:

* Warning! This is a FAST hike... a real workout!
* 5+ miles
* Meetup time 6:00 pm (We hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Difficulty is STRENUOUS!
* 90 minutes

This is a fast, evening Fitness Hike that starts downtown outside (on the sidewalk) of the LanMart Building (Brixx Restaurant, Heebe Jeebe) on Kentucky Street. We head west to Helen Putnam Park (or the Petaluma Water Tanks when DST ends) for some beautiful vistas before returning to our starting point on Kentucky Street. This hike is generally the same route and is focused primarily on fitness.

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking/hiking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

WHAT ABOUT THE DARKNESS?
Bring a SMALL flashlight. The sidewalks can be treacherous in west Petaluma, and you'll want to see those crags, cracks and upheavals in the concrete. Reflective clothing is also recommended so that vehicles can see you!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 mph (22 - 23 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike nearly 3.5 - 4.0 mph (we target a 16 minute mile, with multiple hills!)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?

Please take the time to RSVP YES when you plan on attending an event. It is equally important to keep your RSVP up to date. If you've RSVP'd YES for an event, we are going to wait for you until the departure time. We leave promptly at 6:10 PM, so if you arrive late you can join us along the route. We typically hike the same route for each hike, and our focus is on aerobic exercise.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

SCO Organizers

title: Adult Gymnastics Class
description:
We’re offering Adult Gymnastics Classes for the 18\+ crowd!

Adult Gymnastics classes occur every Tuesday 5:00 PM to 6:30 PM & Friday from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM.

$20 per person, OR pay for a whole 8-week session in advance through our site. You can attend on Tuesday, Friday, or both!

Please bring the class fee in cash at the time of arrival. This can be a DROP IN, so there is no need to sign up online before coming!

If you’ve ever wanted to try out gymnastics or get back into it in adulthood, now is your chance! During our adult classes, open to all genders, our coaches will move at the pace of each student, helping them achieve goals they set for themselves. No experience is necessary to be involved in this class, so this is a great opportunity to learn the basics and get some exercise, no matter what age you are! Try out our trampoline, bars, beam, and other gym equipment in a safe and supportive environment. You can build strength and increase your range of motion while having fun like you’re a kid again.

Ask our coaches what you can work on between classes, and they’ll help personalize your training!

Please wear something comfortable and keep long hair tied back. Skirts and restrictive clothing are not recommended. You must remove your shoes before going onto the mat or using equipment. Please let us know if you have any physical limitations or health conditions that may interfere with doing certain motions. We recommend bringing a water bottle.

You can email us for more info or join our mailing list at: info@sonomagymnasticsacademy.com

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we’ll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We’ll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We’ll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary — rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles to protect the floor.

title: Bachata with ALEX
description:
Bachata with ALEX

Ready to take your bachata to the next level?

This intermediate bachata class is for dancers who have already mastered the basics and are ready for a new challenge. We’ll build on your foundation with a focus on more intricate footwork, technique, and partner work.

Advanced turn patterns and combinations

Styling and body movement to add flair to your dancing

Musicality to connect with the rhythm and emotion of the music

Feeling comfortable with your basic bachata steps and ready for more?

Our intermediate bachata class is designed for dancers who want to elevate their skills. We’ll move beyond the fundamentals to focus on more complex technique, footwork, and partner work.

This class will help you:

Refine your leading and following

Learn combinations and techniques

Develop your personal style and musicality

If you’re ready to add some fire to your dancing, this is the class for you!

Important Details

Basic steps and turns required. We’ll be moving into combinations, so a solid grasp of your basic steps is essential.

No partner necessary: Come solo or bring a friend—either way, you’ll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles: This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can’t wait to see you on the dance floor.

title: Jewish Course in Novato Explores Dreams, Astrology, and the Evil Eye
description:
NOVATO, CA — Chabad Jewish Center of Novato is launching a new fascinating 4 week class: Jewpernatural: Signs, Spirits, and Superstition in Jewish Belief, a new four-week course from the beginning Monday, February 24.

The course addresses questions many people are asking today: Do dreams have meaning? Is there such a thing as destiny? What does Judaism say about astrology and the “evil eye”? How does Jewish tradition understand souls and the afterlife?

Drawing on Talmud, Jewish philosophy, and Kabbalah, Jewpernatural offers a grounded, thoughtful approach to topics that often generate curiosity, skepticism, and uncertainty.

The four sessions include:

Dreams & Direction

Stars & Signs

Jinx & The Evil Eye

Para & Normal (souls, angels, spirits, and the afterlife)

“People are curious about these topics, but they also want serious, authentic answers,” said Rabbi Menachem Landa of Chabad Jewish Center of Novato. “This course helps participants separate myth from meaning and gain practical Jewish perspective for real life.”

The course is open to all, regardless of background or prior Jewish learning.

Event Details What: Jewpernatural (4-weekcourse) When: Begins Monday, February 24 Where: Chabad Jewish Center of Novato Format: In person and Zoom Registration: Jewishnovato.com/Jewpernatural Contact: info@Jewishnovato.com

title: Jeffrey Lewis & the Voltage (21 and Over)
Charleston Food and Wine Festival
description:
The Charleston Wine \+ Food Festival 2026, taking place March 4–8, 2026, celebrates two decades of culinary excellence in Charleston with more than 90 tasting events, chef collaborations, and wine-centric experiences that highlight the Lowcountry’s vibrant food and beverage scene. The festival brings together local and national chefs, sommeliers, and producers for a rich mix of lunches, dinners, tastings, and special events across the city. Among the wine participants, Gundlach Bundschu, the historic family-owned winery from Sonoma County known for its organic estate wines, will be pouring selections and engaging with festival attendees, adding a California wine perspective to Charleston’s celebrated offerings. 

LEARN MORE

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create
