Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

title: Become a Volunteer Seabird Monitor
description:
Join us to learn the skills you need to become a Volunteer Seabird Monitor with Stewards of the Coast and Redwoods.

No experience is necessary.

Stewards’ Seabird Monitoring program began in 2013, thanks to funding from the Bureau of Land Management. Stewards is partnering with the California Coastal National Monument \(CCNM\) to monitor breeding seabirds off the Sonoma Coast and is a local Chapter of the Seabird Protection Network.

Instructor: Hollis Bewley \(Seabird Monitoring Program Coordinator\)

This is a two-part training:

Part 1 of the training on zoom Monday March 9th from 6-7:30pm Seabird Monitoring Training part 1 Join Zoom Meeting: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/84074028922

Part 2 of the training on Thursday, March 19 from 9:30 AM to noon is an experiential training at a location meeting at the Bodega Head East parking lot. We’ll visit one or two of the monitoring sites, practice using the equipment and filling out data forms and sorting cormorant and becoming familiar with other bird species.

You can view a recording of last year’s training here: Seabird training part 1 2025 recording

This was an online introduction to the coastal bird species we will be monitoring and the use of data forms and other information.

Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! 

What you’ll Create

Brand new to the town of Sonoma! Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! Swing is a fun social dance that is an instantly accessible way to enjoy social dancing to swing jazz, blues and rock and roll music. Swing is a form of social partner dance that evolved from Lindy Hop in the 1940s, and is based in six-count patterns that are simplified forms of Lindy Hop patterns. Enjoy a beautiful community of swing dancers and learn how to social dance. Absolutely no experience or partner needed. Simply show up, and I will provide the dance partner, as most students come alone/single. Just bring comfy shoes to dance in and your own water. Class is for singles and couples, alike! Everyone is welcome. We specialize in brand new dancers! Dance with confidence, build community, and learn something new in a friendly and kind environment! If you cannot make the entire series but still want to join a group class, please email or text Jasmine at \(510\) 388-5498 to inquire how to proceed/register.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Free Estate Planning Seminar
description: AT THIS COMPLIMENTARY PRESENTATION, WE WILL DISCUSS SEVERAL TOPICS INCLUDING: One Big Beautiful Bill Act: How the new tax law may impact trusts, estate planning, and family succession strategies. Wills and Living Trusts: Learn the advantages and disadvantages to both. Asset Protection: How to protect your assets and your family’s inheritance from creditors, divorce, and lawsuits. Long Term Care Planning: How to avoid losing your life savings. Next Spouse Protection: How to protect your assets from your surviving spouse’s next spouse. Probate: What is it and how to prevent it. Estate Taxes: What are they, and how to minimize or eliminate. Gifting to Children: How and when to gift your assets and why putting property in children’s names may be a mistake. Special Needs: How to provide for special needs (disabled) children and grandchildren. Legacy Planning: Good planning involves more than money. Learn some powerful tools to help instill important values in younger generation family membe

title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM – 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 – Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you’ll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist:  Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\), Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\) . Inspired by their playful styles, students will design and develop their very own characters—deciding where these characters live, work, play, eat, and sleep! Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.  Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

 watercolor, paint, pens, and collage

 recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use watercolor techniques to add color and mood

How scale helps characters and environments feel real

The arc of a story—beginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 116

title: After-School Adventure Gaming
description:
Tuesdays, February 10 – April 7, 2026 4:00 PM – 6:00 PM Exception: No class March 24

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Teens

Age\(s\)

10-15

$360 – Registration CostPresented by the Sonoma Community Center in partnership with The Game Academy

Join Adventure Gaming classes with The Game Academy! Play D&D, build community, and grow empathy through weekly storytelling sessions.

About the class

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for 2-hour sessions over an 8-week term. Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and tactical challenges to be overcome… all based on the players’ interests. This uniquely tailored experience provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. We hope your child will join us for a new adventure this coming Fall Term at the Sonoma Community Center.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

title: Tuesday Night Fitness Hike: 5+ Fast Miles, Downtown Petaluma and Western Hills
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
WARNING: THE TUESDAY NIGHT FITNESS HIKE IS AN AEROBIC, FAST-PACED URBAN HIKE! WE TARGET A PACE OF 16-MINUTES PER MILE WITH ONLY BRIEF STOPS (TO REGROUP AS NEEDED). OUR SUMMER ROUTE INCLUDES THE HILLS IN HELEN PUTNAM PARK (740 FT. ELEVATION GAIN), AND OUR WINTER ROUTE EXPLORES THE WATER TANKS (690 FT. ELEVATION GAIN). IF YOU FIND YOU ARE HAVING DIFFICULTY KEEPING UP WITH THE LEADERS IN THIS GROUP, PLEASE USE THE OPT-OUT POINT AT THE FIRST MILE OF THE HIKE! ANOTHER OPTION IS OUR WEDNESDAY NIGHT WALK FOR A MORE MODERATE PACE. THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME KEEP THIS HIKE AN AEROBIC WORKOUT!

NOTE:
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is posted on the SCO Calendar every week. Steve Tubbs is shown as the host each week but he might, or might not, show up to the event. This is, more often than not, a small group of regular, fit walkers who show up on time every Tuesday night to enjoy this rigorous walk. We leave promptly at 6:10 pm from the Kentucky Street entrance to the LanMart Building. So, if you don't see Steve on the Tuesday night you are there, you might see him on the next one.

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike, 5+ miles fast paced urban hike:

This Fitness Hike includes multiple steep uphill portions in Helen Putnam Park (during Daylight Savings Time), and at the Petaluma Water Tanks (after Daylight Savings Time ends).

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike:

* Warning! This is a FAST hike... a real workout!
* 5+ miles
* Meetup time 6:00 pm (We hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Difficulty is STRENUOUS!
* 90 minutes

This is a fast, evening Fitness Hike that starts downtown outside (on the sidewalk) of the LanMart Building (Brixx Restaurant, Heebe Jeebe) on Kentucky Street. We head west to Helen Putnam Park (or the Petaluma Water Tanks when DST ends) for some beautiful vistas before returning to our starting point on Kentucky Street. This hike is generally the same route and is focused primarily on fitness.

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking/hiking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

WHAT ABOUT THE DARKNESS?
Bring a SMALL flashlight. The sidewalks can be treacherous in west Petaluma, and you'll want to see those crags, cracks and upheavals in the concrete. Reflective clothing is also recommended so that vehicles can see you!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 mph (22 - 23 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike nearly 3.5 - 4.0 mph (we target a 16 minute mile, with multiple hills!)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?

Please take the time to RSVP YES when you plan on attending an event. It is equally important to keep your RSVP up to date. If you've RSVP'd YES for an event, we are going to wait for you until the departure time. We leave promptly at 6:10 PM, so if you arrive late you can join us along the route. We typically hike the same route for each hike, and our focus is on aerobic exercise.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

SCO Organizers

title: Adult Gymnastics Class
description:
We’re offering Adult Gymnastics Classes for the 18\+ crowd!

Adult Gymnastics classes occur every Tuesday 5:00 PM to 6:30 PM & Friday from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM.

$20 per person, OR pay for a whole 8-week session in advance through our site. You can attend on Tuesday, Friday, or both!

Please bring the class fee in cash at the time of arrival. This can be a DROP IN, so there is no need to sign up online before coming!

If you’ve ever wanted to try out gymnastics or get back into it in adulthood, now is your chance! During our adult classes, open to all genders, our coaches will move at the pace of each student, helping them achieve goals they set for themselves. No experience is necessary to be involved in this class, so this is a great opportunity to learn the basics and get some exercise, no matter what age you are! Try out our trampoline, bars, beam, and other gym equipment in a safe and supportive environment. You can build strength and increase your range of motion while having fun like you’re a kid again.

Ask our coaches what you can work on between classes, and they’ll help personalize your training!

Please wear something comfortable and keep long hair tied back. Skirts and restrictive clothing are not recommended. You must remove your shoes before going onto the mat or using equipment. Please let us know if you have any physical limitations or health conditions that may interfere with doing certain motions. We recommend bringing a water bottle.

You can email us for more info or join our mailing list at: info@sonomagymnasticsacademy.com

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we’ll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We’ll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We’ll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary — rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.

Date & Time: Tuesdays @ 6:30PM – 7:30PM

description:

title: Poetry Book Club: My Infinity by Didi Jackson
description: Each month, the Poetry Book Club meets online to discuss one must-read book of poems, whether a timeless classic or an award-winning contemporary. Led by Napa poet Kathleen Patterson, who has been an enthusiastic book club member since its beginning, meetings are open to all levels of poetry readers, both the curious and the committed. ABOUT THE BOOK WINNER of the 2025 Tennessee Book Award in Poetry In her second collection, My Infinity, Didi Jackson continues her exploration of the paradoxical meaning of a world where joy and sorrow simultaneously coexist. These poems investigate both sacred and natural spaces. Her poems move grief and emotional suffering to language as a site of recovery and renewal. Much of this collection is ordered around the work of the Swedish visual artist Hilma af Klint. As the first artist to arguably use abstraction, her radical work brims with enigmatic botanical images painted to grasp the seemingly boundless and hermetic realm of the dead. Similarly, Jackson's poems explore plant life and natural species in the Green Mountains of Vermont, where perceived thresholds blur in acts of spiritual reimagining. This is a book that questions all that is endless, all that has been thought as limiting, and all that remains unknown. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Didi Jackson is an American poet and professor. In 2020, she released her debut poetry collection, Moon Jar, and in 2024, she released another titled My Infinity, both with Red Hen Press. She is a professor of creative writing at Vanderbilt University

title: Bachata with ALEX
description:
Bachata with ALEX

Ready to take your bachata to the next level?

This intermediate bachata class is for dancers who have already mastered the basics and are ready for a new challenge. We’ll build on your foundation with a focus on more intricate footwork, technique, and partner work.

Advanced turn patterns and combinations

Styling and body movement to add flair to your dancing

Musicality to connect with the rhythm and emotion of the music

Feeling comfortable with your basic bachata steps and ready for more?

Our intermediate bachata class is designed for dancers who want to elevate their skills. We’ll move beyond the fundamentals to focus on more complex technique, footwork, and partner work.

This class will help you:

Refine your leading and following

Learn combinations and techniques

Develop your personal style and musicality

If you’re ready to add some fire to your dancing, this is the class for you!

Important Details

Basic steps and turns required. We’ll be moving into combinations, so a solid grasp of your basic steps is essential.

No partner necessary: Come solo or bring a friend—either way, you’ll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles: This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can’t wait to see you on the dance floor.

title: Jewish Course in Novato Explores Dreams, Astrology, and the Evil Eye
description:
NOVATO, CA — Chabad Jewish Center of Novato is launching a new fascinating 4 week class: Jewpernatural: Signs, Spirits, and Superstition in Jewish Belief, a new four-week course from the beginning Monday, February 24.

The course addresses questions many people are asking today: Do dreams have meaning? Is there such a thing as destiny? What does Judaism say about astrology and the “evil eye”? How does Jewish tradition understand souls and the afterlife?

Drawing on Talmud, Jewish philosophy, and Kabbalah, Jewpernatural offers a grounded, thoughtful approach to topics that often generate curiosity, skepticism, and uncertainty.

The four sessions include:

Dreams & Direction

Stars & Signs

Jinx & The Evil Eye

Para & Normal (souls, angels, spirits, and the afterlife)

“People are curious about these topics, but they also want serious, authentic answers,” said Rabbi Menachem Landa of Chabad Jewish Center of Novato. “This course helps participants separate myth from meaning and gain practical Jewish perspective for real life.”

The course is open to all, regardless of background or prior Jewish learning.

Event Details What: Jewpernatural (4-weekcourse) When: Begins Monday, February 24 Where: Chabad Jewish Center of Novato Format: In person and Zoom Registration: Jewishnovato.com/Jewpernatural Contact: info@Jewishnovato.com

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Art Of Acrylics
description: Suzanne will demonstrate each week as students follow along with weekly painting projects, exploring techniques such as layering thick and thin paint, using gels and palette knife, and applying color theories. Students can work on their own projects as well. Whether you're a beginner or looking to refine your skills, this class covers everything you need to know. You'll get informed instruction on how to begin a piece, from choosing the right materials to selecting the perfect color palette. We'll dive into composition techniques to help you craft a balanced, captivating piece, and walk you through the finishing touches that bring your work to life. Suzanne's artwork ranges from portraits, figurative genre, landscapes and caricatures. She has exhibited in juried shows including The Society of Illustrators in New York and for 10 years at the Southern California Laguna Beach Art Festival. She has taught classes and workshops for many years and led lecture-demos at art associations from California to Washington State. For enrollment and supply list, please text or call Suzanne Carson at 707 888 2083

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: Toddler Storytime
description: Get a jump start on reading at this early literacy storytime geared just for toddlers using a variety of stories, songs, and rhymes. These activities provide a fun environment for toddlers to exercise important motor skills and practice using their vocabulary. Children and their grownups are encouraged to engage with the stories and activities together. Afterwards, join us for Stay & Play! We'll have a variety of toys and activities available so come hang out. This program will be 20 minutes of stories and songs followed by 25 minutes of stay and play. Recommended for children age 18 months to 3 years and their caregivers.

title: Wee Wednesdays - 6-18 months

description: Join us every week for a fun, interactive session of stories and songs in English and Spanish! Appropriate for children ages 0-5 and their families. We look forward to seeing you!

title: Family Law Consultations at Sonoma County Public Law Library
description: Local volunteer attorneys offer free legal information and referral for matters of family law only. These lawyer consultations will last up to 20 minutes. Sign-ups are first come, first served in person and begin at 10 am. \(30 minutes before the program begins\) The attorneys are volunteers and provide only legal information. They do not provide specific legal advice and should not be considered as personal lawyers for any reason. You will be required to sign a waiver before speaking to an attorney that states that no attorney-client relationship is being created with this free service. No language translation services or interpreters are offered or provided by library staff. Participants must bring their own interpreter if one is needed. Participants may also bring support persons, family members or other affiliated persons to meet with the attorney together. For deaf and hard of hearing participants, the Sonoma County Bar Association will make arrangements for ASL interpretation with at least two days' advance notice. Please contact Reception@SonomaCountyBar.org or \(707\) 542-1190 ext.100 for assistance. The program is a partnership between the Sonoma County Library, the Sonoma County Law Library, and the Sonoma County Bar Association and is staffed by volunteer attorneys. Learn more here.

title: Family Storytime
description: Our family storytimes are great for the whole family. Have children of different ages? Bring them all! These stories and activities are for everyone.

title: Spanish Music & Movement
description: This program is presented in Spanish. Spanish Music & Movement is a tour of culture, language, and fun! This presentation is not for sitting - your family will be active characters in these adventures, participating with colorful scarves, instruments, and animals as you move to the sound of language. Even if you are not fluent Spanish speakers, see the language come alive through the animated and energetic activities designed for children under 6 years and family.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Author Talk: Nightmare Obscura

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         **Offered Daily:** 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

title: Next-Level Drawing
description:
Schedule

Wednesday, March 11 – April 22, 2026 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

Intermediate

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$225 – Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20″ x 26″ drawing board with clips, 18 “x 24” Strathmore drawing pad \(other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality\), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal \(Char-kole brand black\), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black \(one fine-tip and one medium-tip\).Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Rainbow Book Club: Carry On by Rainbow Rowell
description: The Rainbow Book Club is cohosted by Mindy from Napa County Library and Napa Bookmine staff members Kass and Jules. The book club focuses on books that explore and embrace queer identity. This is a free event, but we appreciate your RSVP so we can plan for your attendance! We look forward to welcoming you. ABOUT THE BOOK \#1 New York Times best seller! Booklist Editors’ Choice 2015 - Youth! Named a "Best Book of 2015" by Time Magazine, School Library Journal, Barnes & Noble, NPR, PopSugar, The Millions, and The News & Observer! Simon Snow is the worst Chosen One who's ever been chosen. That's what his roommate, Baz, says. And Baz might be evil and a vampire and a complete git, but he's probably right. Half the time, Simon can't even make his wand work, and the other half, he starts something on fire. His mentor's avoiding him, his girlfriend broke up with him, and there's a magic-eating monster running around, wearing Simon's face. Baz would be having a field day with all this, if he were here--it's their last year at the Watford School of Magicks, and Simon's infuriating nemesis didn't even bother to show up. Carry On is a ghost story, a love story and a mystery. It has just as much kissing and talking as you'd expect from a Rainbow Rowell story - but far, far more monsters. "Rowell imbues her magic with awe and spectacle. It's a powerful, politically minded allegory about sexual, ethnic and class identity - with a heady shot of teenage lust." —New York Times Book Review "It’s a brilliantly addictive, genuinely romantic story about teenagers who can’t be neatly sorted into houses, coping with stress and loss and the confusion of just trying to be who they are. It’s as if Rowell turned the Harry Potter books inside out, and is showing us the marvelous, subversive stuffing inside." —Time Magazine "Full of heart and humor, this fantastical tale is a worthy addition to the wizarding-school genre." —People Magazine ABOUT THE AUTHOR Rainbow Rowell is the award-winning \#1 New York Times bestselling author of Eleanor & Park and the Simon Snow Trilogy, plus several other novels, short stories, and comics. She lives in Omaha, Nebraska, just like most of her characters.

title: Spring ESL Evening Class: Beginning Level

title: Vallejo Library Poets Review
description: Meet Your Poetic Cousins & Ancestors This guided review of legacy poets from around the world is an intimate exploration group, meeting to review many fine & famous \(or infamous, or not-so-famous\) poets of the past & present who have left a mark on literature, the art of poetry, and society as a whole. JOIN US to discover \(or re-discover\) male, female & other poets of all ethnicities. We'll review poets romantic & erotic, political, pastoral & personal, dreamers, ragers, firebrands, sensualists - poets of all colors & stripes - names you will recognize, and \(we hope\) many you don't recognise. To keep in touch with interested poets & potential participants, the library will publish this growing list on its website of all the poets currently suggested for review, with a short bio & picture, plus a selection of poems titles for all the poets listed. Our Facebook page will also show reviews & suggestions from participants. We also plan a separate website in the future. On the Second Wednesday of each month, we will gather for a round-table review of several poets, with each participant at that meeting having chosen a poet to explore for the evening. Participants will have unlimited time before the meeting to read about their chosen poet, explore one or more biographies & several poems, and sketch out in advance a piece to read at the next gathering. We will open with a participant reading on of the chosen poet's poems, then we will open a discussion among the participants, after which that participant can read his or her written offering. The next participant will then read a chosen poem, followed by a discussion, as well as his or her written offering. This pattern will follow until all the participants have read - ending at 8pm. Depending on how many people are present, each segment will have to be timed so that everyone can read. A working list at press-time includes: Alex Pushkin Alla Gutnikova Allen Ginsburg Andrei Codrescu Anna Akmatova Cesar Vallejo Dylan Thomas E.E. title: Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown & Riverfront
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown and Riverfront

* Want to walk for fitness and exercise?
* New to walking and want to build up stamina?
* Like a slower pace than our Tuesday Night Fitness Hike?
* Would walking with a committed group of walkers help you?

If you said yes to any of these, then the Wednesday Night Walk in Petaluma is for you. We start at Aqus Cafe and take in the West Side of town, including some of Downtown, the Waterfront and a few of the Historic home of old Petaluma. We walk about 3-1/2 to 4-1/2 miles depending on weather conditions and the pace of the group that night.

Afterward if you have the time, join us at Aqus Cafe for a bite to eat and some liquid refreshment before heading home. Aqus Cafe is a true gem of a gathering place, restaurant, coffee house, and live music venue. But it's the people on either side of the counter that make this place so special.

DETAILS:

* Meetup time: 6:00pm (we hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Meetup location: Aqus Cafe
* Distance: 3.5 to 4-1/2 miles
* Duration: 75-80 minutes
* Pace: Easy/Moderate (about 2.5-3 mph or 20-24 minute miles)
* Difficulty: Easy (if you've walked 3-4 miles recently)
* Hills: Mostly flat with a few small and easy to climb hills
* Optional After-Hike Gathering at Aqus Cafe

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 - 3 mph (20-24 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is about 3.5-4 mph (15-17 minute miles)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks. You will not be spammed. If you are, let me know. Spamming will not be tolerated.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?
It's important to RSVP for these walks. When all the people have arrived for a walk that have RSVP'd, we leave... it might mean we leave early. If you didn't RSVP we are not going to wait for you. Plus, it's just a nice courtesy to the organizer and other participants. Please take the time to RSVP.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

Gary
SCO Organizer

title: George Kahumoku Jr & Led Kaapana & Sonny Lim
description:
Masters of Hawaiian Music features three of the most popular musicians from Maui’s renowned “Slack Key Show.” 4-time Grammy winner, slack key guitar master George Kahumoku Jr, National Heritage Fellow Led Kaapana, whose picking style of slack key guitar is unrivaled, and Sonny Lim, who plays both lap steel \(invented in Hawai‘i\) and slack key guitar. Together they share Hawai‘i’s unique slack key \(open tuning\) guitar styles and songs that trace their roots to the paniolos \(Hawaiian cowboys\), along with delightful stories of Hawai‘i and their lives in music.

=====

Hora del espectáculo: 7:00 p. m.

Maestros de la Música Hawaiana presenta a tres de los músicos más populares del famoso "Slack Key Show" de Maui: George Kahumoku Jr., cuatro veces ganador del Grammy y maestro de la guitarra slack key; Led Kaapana, miembro del Patrimonio Nacional, cuyo estilo de punteo con la guitarra slack key es inigualable; y Sonny Lim, quien toca tanto el lap steel \(inventado en Hawái\) como la guitarra slack key. Juntos comparten los singulares estilos de guitarra slack key \(afinación abierta\) de Hawái y canciones con raíces en los paniolos \(vaqueros hawaianos\), además de encantadoras historias de Hawái y su vida musical.

title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Free Estate Planning Seminar
description: AT THIS COMPLIMENTARY PRESENTATION, WE WILL DISCUSS SEVERAL TOPICS INCLUDING: One Big Beautiful Bill Act: How the new tax law may impact trusts, estate planning, and family succession strategies. Wills and Living Trusts: Learn the advantages and disadvantages to both. Asset Protection: How to protect your assets and your family’s inheritance from creditors, divorce, and lawsuits. Long Term Care Planning: How to avoid losing your life savings. Next Spouse Protection: How to protect your assets from your surviving spouse’s next spouse. Probate: What is it and how to prevent it. Estate Taxes: What are they, and how to minimize or eliminate. Gifting to Children: How and when to gift your assets and why putting property in children’s names may be a mistake. Special Needs: How to provide for special needs (disabled) children and grandchildren. Legacy Planning: Good planning involves more than money. Learn some powerful tools to help instill important values in younger generation family membe

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Lawyers in the Library: Employment & Civil Law
description: Local volunteer attorneys offer free legal information and referral for matters of civil and employment law only. These lawyer consultations will last up to 20 minutes. Sign-ups are first come, first served in person and begin at 11:30 am. \(30 minutes before the program begins\) The attorneys are volunteers and provide only legal information. They do not provide specific legal advice and should not be considered as personal lawyers for any reason. You will be required to sign a waiver before speaking to an attorney that states that no attorney-client relationship is being created with this free service. No language translation services or interpreters are offered or provided by library staff. Participants must bring their own interpreter if one is needed. Participants may also bring support persons, family members or other affiliated persons to meet with the attorney together. For deaf and hard of hearing participants, the Sonoma County Bar Association will make arrangements for ASL interpretation with at least two days' advance notice. Please contact Reception@SonomaCountyBar.org or \(707\) 542-1190 ext.100 for assistance. The program is a partnership between the Sonoma County Library, the Sonoma County Law Library, and the Sonoma County Bar Association and is staffed by volunteer attorneys. Learn more about the Lawyers in the Library program here.

title: Barbies & Bags Workshop
description:
Schedule

Sunday, February 15, 2026 1:00 PM – 4:00 PM

Location

Room 201, Fiber Arts Studio

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Programming, Sustainability

Age\(s\)

All Ages are welcome to attend Children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult

$25 – One Bag or Doll Entry $40 – Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 – 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we’ll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we’re expanding the exhibit to include bags—think totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It’s a joy to see your art find a new home—and to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

title: Author Talks: Journeys of Literary Magic with Kate Quinn
description: Register here: You're invited to join us for a virtual conversation with acclaimed author Kate Quinn about her latest fantastical work, The Astral Library, which poses the question: Have you ever wished you could live inside a book? Welcome to the Astral Library, where books are not just objects, but doors to new worlds, new lives, and new futures. About the Author: Kate Quinn is the New York Times and USA Today bestselling author of historical fiction. A lifelong history buff, she has written four novels in the Empress of Rome Saga and two books set in the Italian Renaissance before turning to the 20th century with The Alice Network, The Huntress, The Rose Code, The Diamond Eye, and The Briar Club. The Astral Library is her first foray into magic realism.

title: Happy Hour Crafts
description:
The Rebel Craft Collective
Wine + tasty snacks + your latest project and a friendly group of likeminded crafters... what better way to unwind? Come join us!

This is a relaxed, drop-in-friendly event. Come when you can, leave when you must. Newcomers and occasional-comers are always welcome!

**What do we mean by “crafts”?**
Whatever “craft” means to you! And whatever is portable enough to bring to a wine bar. Knitting, crochet, and other fiber arts are most common, but we have also warmly welcomed people who sketch, color, embroider, bead, and more. If your craft isn’t portable, we will happily ooh and aah over photos of your work-in-progress, or chat about your plans for your next project.

**Health & Safety**
Masks are very welcome, and nobody will pressure you to eat or drink. If the weather is nice, we will try to sit outside. If you aren’t eating/drinking during the event, please consider ordering some of La Dolce Vita’s delicious food to-go, in order to help support our gracious, long-time venue.

**Parking**
Parking in downtown Petaluma is free, but street parking has a strictly enforced 2 hour limit until 6pm. To park for longer, try the nearest garage:

* The Second Street Garage entrance is located on C Street between First and Second Streets. It's all day parking on every level and a short walk to La Dolce Vita.

**Ages**
It's a wine bar, so this event is for adult crafters (though you're certainly not required to drink wine!). We’re okay with babes-in-arms if you are, but this is not the right setting for wee crafters who are moving about on their own.

title: Opening Reception: Americana Reimagined and States of Anxiety, States of Hope works by Inez Storer
description:
Join us for the opening reception of PAC's Americana Reimagined exhibition and Inez Storer's States of Anxiety, States of Hope: Thursday, March 12, 5:30-7:30pmAdmission is Free but space is limited so reserve your ticket/s now before it is sold out.

About Americana Reimagined: On the 250th anniversary of the founding of the United States, Americana Reimagined invited artists from across the greater Bay Area to explore, reinterpret, and reimagine the visual language of “Americana”. This juried exhibition looks beyond nostalgia to examine how familiar symbols, stories, and styles evolve over time—bridging the past and present through creativity and craft. 

“Americana” has long served as a reflection of everyday life and culture, from small-town iconography and handmade crafts to design movements and popular imagery. In Americana Reimagined artists reexamine this broad theme, juxtaposing the old and the new, and honoring timeless motifs while offering fresh perspectives on what they mean today.

Jurors 

Donna Seager, Donna Seager Fine Arts & Artists' Books  Richard Neill, Multimedia Artist and Film curator Simon Corwin, Petaluma Artist and Jewelry

States of Anxiety, States of HopeExhibition Dates: March 12 - April 18, 2026Opening Reception: Thursday, March 12, 5:30-7:30pm

About States of Anxiety, States of Hope: This exhibition presents a selection of works by artist Inez Storer that reflect on the emotional, cultural, and political complexities of contemporary life. Building on themes explored in Americana Reimagined, Storer's paintings offer a layered meditation on identity, memory, and collective experience in times of uncertainty and transformation.

Through her distinctive magical realist collage method, Storer constructs richly textured visual narratives that merge personal history with broader social realities. Her works are composed of fragments—symbols, images, and artifacts drawn from her life and interests.

Storer's paintings guide the viewer on a journey through both historical memory and internal landscapes. They balance darkness and light, anxiety and hope.  She asks us to reflect on the conditions of our moment. States of Anxiety, States of Hope affirms art's capacity to illuminate struggle while nurturing resilience, empathy, and connection.

title: States of Anxiety, States of Hope | Works of Inez Storer
description: [ { "type": "highlight", "id": "481f9063-c358-4f54-ba25-2bb0e1e78086", "shape": "underline", "isFront": false, "isAnimationEnabled": false, "animation": "draw", "duration": 0.5, "direction": "right", "color": { "type": "THEME_COLOR" }, "thickness": { "unit": "em", "value": 0.1 }, "linecap": "square" } ] States of Anxiety, States of Hope Exhibition Dates: March 12 - April 18, 2026 Opening Reception: Thursday, March 12, 5:30-7:30pm States of Anxiety, States of Hope  presents a selection of works by artist Inez Storer that reflect on the emotional, cultural, and political complexities of contemporary life. Building on themes explored in   Americana Reimagined ,  Storer’s paintings offer a layered meditation on identity, memory, and collective experience in times of uncertainty and transformation. Through her distinctive magical realist collage method, Storer constructs richly textured visual narratives that merge personal history with broader social realities. Her works are composed of fragments—symbols, images, and artifacts drawn from her life and interests. Storer's paintings guide the viewer on a journey through both historical memory and internal landscapes. They balance darkness and light, anxiety and hope.  She asks us to reflect on the conditions of our moment. States of Anxiety, States of Hope affirms art’s capacity to illuminate struggle while nurturing resilience, empathy, and connection. Biography Storer lives in Inverness, California, and has a studio in Point Reyes Station. Born in Santa Monica in 1933 to a Catholic father and Jewish mother, she spent time on Hollywood movie sets where her father worked as an art director. Influenced by stage design, her work often creates a sense of “theatrical space” and reflects her ancestry. Shortly before her death, her mother revealed that she had fled Germany to escape Nazism. Storer later learned of cousins who escaped on the Kindertransport. The frustration of being kept from the truth has infused her work with a distinct angst. Her work is held in many collections including the Jewish Museum in New York, Manetti Shrem Museum of Art at UC Davis, Oakland Museum of Art , the de Young Museum, San José Museum of Art, Monterey Museum of Art, Missoula Museum of Art, National Museum of American Jewish History, and the National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington, DC. At the same time, our friends at IceHouse Gallery will hold a companion exhibition of Storer’s Works on Paper. Exhibition dates are March 7 - March 28. title: Crochet for Beginners and Beyond
description:
Schedule

Tuesdays, March 3 – 24, 2026 6:00 PM – 8:00 PM

Location

Room 201, Fiber Arts Studio

Experience Level

All Levels

Fiber Arts

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$80 – Registration CostLearn to crochet or expand your skills in four relaxed Tuesday evening sessions. Beginners master foundational stitches; experienced crafters get project guidance.

About the Class

Have you always wanted to learn to crochet – or are you ready to build on the skills you already have? Join us in the Fiber Arts Studio for four relaxed Tuesday evening sessions dedicated to learning and practicing crochet. Beginners will start with the essentials: how to hold the hook comfortably, maintain even tension, and work the foundational stitches – chain, single crochet, and double crochet. Students with prior experience are welcome to begin a new project or bring a work-in-progress for guidance and skill-building. All materials are provided for beginners. Returning or experienced crocheters may bring their own supplies or use yarn available in the studio.

title: Samba no Pé - First Class
description:
Get ready to feel the rhythm and energy of Rio de Janeiro! Samba no Pé \(Samba in the Foot\) is the captivating solo style of samba danced in the streets and at Carnival, known for its rapid, intricate footwork and infectious hip movements.

You will learn

The Basic Step: You will master the signature quick-quick-slow rhythm that defines Samba no Pé.

Arm & Hip Styling: You will learn how to add the authentic flair, movement, and energy that makes Brazilian samba so captivating.

Technique & Posture: You will receive tips on proper body alignment to help you dance longer, faster, and more safely.

Rhythm & Musicality: You will learn how to connect your movement directly to the irresistible beat of the bateria \(the samba drum section\).

This class is perfect for anyone looking to connect with the vibrant spirit of Brazil, improve coordination, and get a fantastic workout—all while learning the foundational steps of this iconic dance. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Date & Time: Thursdays @6:30PM – 7:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Greg Lamboy - Live Every 2nd Thursday at Finnegan's Marin
description:
Greg Lamboy has called Finnegan's Marin home for over a decade. Every second Thursday of the month, this Tiburon-based troubadour settles into the warmly lit corner of Novato's beloved neighborhood pub and does what he does best: connects. An accomplished guitarist and award-winning songwriter, Lamboy has earned his stripes across the Bay Area scene both as a solo artist and as frontman of Pacific Standard, his soulful Americana band. His five acclaimed albums draw praise for melodies that are pitch-perfect and lyrics that feel like they were written specifically for you. At Finnegan's, a lively Irish pub and American bar and grill along a tree-lined street in downtown Novato, Lamboy's intimate style is perfectly at home. No pretense. No distance. Just a strong clear voice, commanding guitar, and songs that, as one critic put it, lift you above the everyday. Come early, grab a pint, and let the music find you. https://greglamboy.com/

*Every second Thursday of the month | Finnegan's Marin, 877 Grant Ave, Novato | Free*

title: Forró Dance with Eric and Abigail
description:
Get ready to connect, spin, and glide to the irresistible rhythms of Forró! Originating in the Northeast of Brazil, Forró is a captivating partner dance known for its close embrace, playful steps, and infectious, feel-good music. It is a social dance that will enrich your life, perfect for a night out or a casual gathering.

You Will Learn:

The Basic Step & Close Embrace: You will master the foundational quick-quick-slow rhythm and learn how to comfortably and confidently navigate the essential close-hold connection that defines Forró.

Leading & Following Techniques: Discover the clear, subtle body cues required to effortlessly lead your partner through turns and variations, and how to follow with grace and responsiveness.

Traveling & Stationary Patterns: Learn fundamental steps like the ‘Caminhada’ \(walking step\) and common stationary turns that will allow you to dance on any size floor.

Rhythm & Musicality: Connect your movement to the distinct musical styles of Forró—from the mellow ‘Xote’ to the faster, more energetic ‘Pé-de-Serra.’

This class is perfect for anyone looking to learn a social partner dance, connect with Brazilian culture, and enjoy a vibrant, community atmosphere. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Class Details

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

Date & Time: Thursdays @7:30PM – 8:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

description:

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Big and Small; Pinching Pots with Dan Clauson
description:

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Art Departments, Ceramics

Age\(s\)

17\+

$230 Registration Fee $30 Materials Fee $260 Total Registration Fee

A class that is all about pinching! With instructor Dan, students will learn handbuilding methods to coil and pitch their vessels. With specific direction in learning the techniques to build any size of pot, from a large scale vessel to a small cup. We will learn how to support scaling up our forms through drying methods, interior ‘bone’ structure, and mastering directionality with our hands. There will be a focus on how we each make a mark upon a pot, and how to do so with purpose. Each student will create work that reflects the time-honored nature of handbuilding; when intention is given to the silhouette of a form, the lip of a cup, and/or the comfort of a handle. Each class will involve a warmup, a demo, and worktime. Most classes will have \(fun&thoughtful\) homework.

Required Class Supply List

title: Introduction to the Art of Bookmaking
description:
Schedule

Fridays, February 20 – March 13, 2026 10:00 AM – 1:00 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Fiber Arts, Other, Printmaking

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$220 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $250 – Total Registration CostLearn essential bookbinding techniques in this 4-week introduction to book arts. Create zines, pamphlets, accordion folds, and more using traditional paper-folding and stitching methods.

What you’ll do

Join guest artist, Bettina Pauly in this incredible introduction to book arts! The art of bookmaking, otherwise known as bookbinding, is the physical craft of creating an artistic book from start to finish. In this introductory 4-session class, you will learn the basic use of bookbinding tools and materials, along with simple bookbinding structures that utilize paper softcovers. Students will learn several basic bookbinding structures and stitches that every beginning book artist should know! Experience technical skills such as paper folding, cutting, sewing and gluing, mixed with artistic elements of design to create functional, elegant objects built for storytelling. The instructor will offer guided instruction in a supportive learning environment with a limited class size. Each 3-hour session will meet for four consecutive weeks and focus on the following core bookbinding techniques:

Session 1: Intro to tools and paper folding; one sheet wonder zine, ‘pants’ fold with and without cover, map folds

Session 2: Pamphlets, and Japanese stab hole binding; three hole pamphlet stitch, five hole pamphlet stitch, Japanese stab binding two holes / five holes 

Session 3: Accordion folds; accordion fold, accordion fold tipped into envelope cover, accordion fold with non-adhesive cover

Session 4: Magic wallets, and personal projects

The class materials fee will include paper and all the tools needed to create each of these projects. Students will be able to take home all of their book projects at the end of the workshop. Please note: This class requires some hand dexterity to maneuver bookbinding tools. Participants should feel comfortable using tools with sharp edges such as an awl, x-acto knife, and scissors.
