title: March Month of Flowers Challenge
description:
**Starting March 1st begins the "March Month of Flowers Challenge" (online).** 

You'll receive a list of prompts for every day in March. 

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM – 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 – Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you’ll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist:  Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\), Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\) . Inspired by their playful styles, students will design and develop their very own characters—deciding where these characters live, work, play, eat, and sleep! Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.  Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

 watercolor, paint, pens, and collage

 recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use watercolor techniques to add color and mood

How scale helps characters and environments feel real

The arc of a story—beginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

description:

10-15

$360 – Registration CostPresented by the Sonoma Community Center in partnership with The Game Academy

Join Adventure Gaming classes with The Game Academy! Play D&D, build community, and grow empathy through weekly storytelling sessions.

About the class

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for 2-hour sessions over an 8-week term. Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and tactical challenges to be overcome… all based on the players’ interests. This uniquely tailored experience provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. We hope your child will join us for a new adventure this coming Fall Term at the Sonoma Community Center.

title: Tuesday Night Fitness Hike: 5+ Fast Miles, Downtown Petaluma and Western Hills
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
WARNING: THE TUESDAY NIGHT FITNESS HIKE IS AN AEROBIC, FAST-PACED URBAN HIKE! WE TARGET A PACE OF 16-MINUTES PER MILE WITH ONLY BRIEF STOPS (TO REGROUP AS NEEDED). OUR SUMMER ROUTE INCLUDES THE HILLS IN HELEN PUTNAM PARK (740 FT. ELEVATION GAIN), AND OUR WINTER ROUTE EXPLORES THE WATER TANKS (690 FT. ELEVATION GAIN). IF YOU FIND YOU ARE HAVING DIFFICULTY KEEPING UP WITH THE LEADERS IN THIS GROUP, PLEASE USE THE OPT-OUT POINT AT THE FIRST MILE OF THE HIKE! ANOTHER OPTION IS OUR WEDNESDAY NIGHT WALK FOR A MORE MODERATE PACE. THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME KEEP THIS HIKE AN AEROBIC WORKOUT!

NOTE:
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is posted on the SCO Calendar every week. Steve Tubbs is shown as the host each week but he might, or might not, show up to the event. This is, more often than not, a small group of regular, fit walkers who show up on time every Tuesday night to enjoy this rigorous walk. We leave promptly at 6:10 pm from the Kentucky Street entrance to the LanMart Building. So, if you don't see Steve on the Tuesday night you are there, you might see him on the next one.

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike, 5+ miles fast paced urban hike:

This Fitness Hike includes multiple steep uphill portions in Helen Putnam Park (during Daylight Savings Time), and at the Petaluma Water Tanks (after Daylight Savings Time ends).

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike:

* Warning! This is a FAST hike... a real workout!
* 5+ miles
* Meetup time 6:00 pm (We hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Difficulty is STRENUOUS!
* 90 minutes

This is a fast, evening Fitness Hike that starts downtown outside (on the sidewalk) of the LanMart Building (Brixx Restaurant, Heebe Jeebe) on Kentucky Street. We head west to Helen Putnam Park (or the Petaluma Water Tanks when DST ends) for some beautiful vistas before returning to our starting point on Kentucky Street. This hike is generally the same route and is focused primarily on fitness.

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking/hiking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

WHAT ABOUT THE DARKNESS?
Bring a SMALL flashlight. The sidewalks can be treacherous in west Petaluma, and you'll want to see those crags, cracks and upheavals in the concrete. Reflective clothing is also recommended so that vehicles can see you!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 mph (22 - 23 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike nearly 3.5 - 4.0 mph (we target a 16 minute mile, with multiple hills!)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?

Please take the time to RSVP YES when you plan on attending an event. It is equally important to keep your RSVP up to date. If you've RSVP'd YES for an event, we are going to wait for you until the departure time. We leave promptly at 6:10 PM, so if you arrive late you can join us along the route. We typically hike the same route for each hike, and our focus is on aerobic exercise.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

SCO Organizers

title: Adult Gymnastics Class
description:
We’re offering Adult Gymnastics Classes for the 18\+ crowd!

Adult Gymnastics classes occur every Tuesday 5:00 PM to 6:30 PM & Friday from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM.

$20 per person, OR pay for a whole 8-week session in advance through our site. You can attend on Tuesday, Friday, or both!

Please bring the class fee in cash at the time of arrival. This can be a DROP IN, so there is no need to sign up online before coming!

If you’ve ever wanted to try out gymnastics or get back into it in adulthood, now is your chance! During our adult classes, open to all genders, our coaches will move at the pace of each student, helping them achieve goals they set for themselves. No experience is necessary to be involved in this class, so this is a great opportunity to learn the basics and get some exercise, no matter what age you are! Try out our trampoline, bars, beam, and other gym equipment in a safe and supportive environment. You can build strength and increase your range of motion while having fun like you’re a kid again.

Ask our coaches what you can work on between classes, and they’ll help personalize your training!

Please wear something comfortable and keep long hair tied back. Skirts and restrictive clothing are not recommended. You must remove your shoes before going onto the mat or using equipment. Please let us know if you have any physical limitations or health conditions that may interfere with doing certain motions. We recommend bringing a water bottle.

You can email us for more info or join our mailing list at: info@sonomagymnasticsacademy.com

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we’ll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We’ll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We’ll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary — rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.

Date & Time: Tuesdays @ 6:30PM – 7:30PM

title: Bachata with ALEX
description:
Bachata with ALEX

Ready to take your bachata to the next level?

This intermediate bachata class is for dancers who have already mastered the basics and are ready for a new challenge. We’ll build on your foundation with a focus on more intricate footwork, technique, and partner work.

Advanced turn patterns and combinations

Styling and body movement to add flair to your dancing

Musicality to connect with the rhythm and emotion of the music

Feeling comfortable with your basic bachata steps and ready for more?

Our intermediate bachata class is designed for dancers who want to elevate their skills. We’ll move beyond the fundamentals to focus on more complex technique, footwork, and partner work.

This class will help you:

Refine your leading and following

Learn combinations and techniques

Develop your personal style and musicality

If you’re ready to add some fire to your dancing, this is the class for you!

Important Details

Basic steps and turns required. We’ll be moving into combinations, so a solid grasp of your basic steps is essential.

No partner necessary: Come solo or bring a friend—either way, you’ll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles: This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can’t wait to see you on the dance floor.

title: Jewish Course in Novato Explores Dreams, Astrology, and the Evil Eye
description:
NOVATO, CA — Chabad Jewish Center of Novato is launching a new fascinating 4 week class: Jewpernatural: Signs, Spirits, and Superstition in Jewish Belief, a new four-week course from the beginning Monday, February 24.

The course addresses questions many people are asking today: Do dreams have meaning? Is there such a thing as destiny? What does Judaism say about astrology and the “evil eye”? How does Jewish tradition understand souls and the afterlife?

Drawing on Talmud, Jewish philosophy, and Kabbalah, Jewpernatural offers a grounded, thoughtful approach to topics that often generate curiosity, skepticism, and uncertainty.

The four sessions include:

Dreams & Direction

Stars & Signs

Jinx & The Evil Eye

Para & Normal (souls, angels, spirits, and the afterlife)

“People are curious about these topics, but they also want serious, authentic answers,” said Rabbi Menachem Landa of Chabad Jewish Center of Novato. “This course helps participants separate myth from meaning and gain practical Jewish perspective for real life.”

The course is open to all, regardless of background or prior Jewish learning.

Event Details What: Jewpernatural (4-weekcourse) When: Begins Monday, February 24 Where: Chabad Jewish Center of Novato Format: In person and Zoom Registration: Jewishnovato.com/Jewpernatural Contact: info@Jewishnovato.com

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

description: Suzanne will demonstrate each week as students follow along with weekly painting projects, exploring techniques such as layering thick and thin paint, using gels and palette knife, and applying color theories. Students can work on their own projects as well. Whether you're a beginner or looking to refine your skills, this class covers everything you need to know. You'll get informed instruction on how to begin a piece, from choosing the right materials to selecting the perfect color palette. We'll dive into composition techniques to help you craft a balanced, captivating piece, and walk you through the finishing touches that bring your work to life. Suzanne's artwork ranges from portraits, figurative genre, landscapes and caricatures. title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative

We'll have a variety of toys and activities available so come hang out. This program will be 20 minutes of stories and songs followed by 25 minutes of stay and play. title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

$225 – Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20″ x 26″ drawing board with clips, 18 “x 24” Strathmore drawing pad \(other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality\), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal \(Char-kole brand black\), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black \(one fine-tip and one medium-tip\).Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

description:

You will get to be part of a live studio audience through a guided tasting with special guests from the culinary and wine industries who will join along the way. Each event invites you to learn and connect through exceptional wines, thoughtful pairings, and lively conversation.  

Why does Chardonnay taste so different from place to place—and why does limestone matter so much? Find out at a live, in-person tasting during CIA at Copia’s *Quench at Copia* series led by Master Sommelier Andrea Immer Robinson with special guest and legendary winemaker, David Ramey. In this experience, you’ll be focusing on one of the “GOAT”-ed Grapes: Chardonnay! You’ll explore standout Chardonnay styles side by side, paired with bites designed to amplify flavor and texture. Expect “aha” moments, lively conversation, and great white wine.

title: Sweet and Savory Tamales: Traditional Techniques
description:
Schedule

Wednesday, March 18, 2026 5:00 PM – 8:00 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Bilingual, Culinary Arts

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$100 – Registration CostMaster traditional tamal-making with sweet and savory variations. Learn masa preparation, filling techniques, and steaming methods for authentic results.

What you’ll do

Dive into the rich tradition of tamal-making in this comprehensive hands-on class exploring both sweet and savory variations of this beloved Latin American dish. Whether you’re new to tamales or looking to refine your technique, you’ll gain confidence in every step of the process from preparing masa to achieving perfectly steamed results. Learn to work with masa dough, understanding the proper texture and consistency that creates light, tender tamales. You’ll prepare savory fillings that might include seasoned pork, chicken with salsa verde, cheese with peppers, or black bean and vegetable options. Explore sweet variations featuring cinnamon, fruit, chocolate, or traditional piloncillo for dessert-style tamales that are perfect for celebrations or breakfast. Master the art of spreading masa evenly on corn husks, portioning fillings appropriately, and folding techniques that ensure your tamales hold together beautifully during steaming. You’ll learn the secrets of proper steaming for consistent cooking and discover tips for making large batches ahead for freezing. Tamales are central to celebrations and family gatherings across Latin America, and this class honors that tradition while making the process approachable for home cooks. Leave with recipes, techniques, and the skills to host your own tamalada.Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown & Riverfront
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown and Riverfront

* Want to walk for fitness and exercise?
* New to walking and want to build up stamina?
* Like a slower pace than our Tuesday Night Fitness Hike?
* Would walking with a committed group of walkers help you?

If you said yes to any of these, then the Wednesday Night Walk in Petaluma is for you. We start at Aqus Cafe and take in the West Side of town, including some of Downtown, the Waterfront and a few of the Historic home of old Petaluma. We walk about 3-1/2 to 4-1/2 miles depending on weather conditions and the pace of the group that night.

Afterward if you have the time, join us at Aqus Cafe for a bite to eat and some liquid refreshment before heading home. Aqus Cafe is a true gem of a gathering place, restaurant, coffee house, and live music venue. But it's the people on either side of the counter that make this place so special.

DETAILS:

* Meetup time: 6:00pm (we hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Meetup location: Aqus Cafe
* Distance: 3.5 to 4-1/2 miles
* Duration: 75-80 minutes
* Pace: Easy/Moderate (about 2.5-3 mph or 20-24 minute miles)
* Difficulty: Easy (if you've walked 3-4 miles recently)
* Hills: Mostly flat with a few small and easy to climb hills
* Optional After-Hike Gathering at Aqus Cafe

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 - 3 mph (20-24 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is about 3.5-4 mph (15-17 minute miles)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks. You will not be spammed. If you are, let me know. Spamming will not be tolerated.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?
It's important to RSVP for these walks. When all the people have arrived for a walk that have RSVP'd, we leave... it might mean we leave early. If you didn't RSVP we are not going to wait for you. Plus, it's just a nice courtesy to the organizer and other participants. Please take the time to RSVP.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

Gary
SCO Organizer

Create an art piece related to the prompt.

Share in our private Facebook group.

Be inspired and give inspiration to others.

**Only $5**, so everyone can join and share in this creative adventure!

***March Month of Flowers* Challenge** is here to give you a creative outlet, some structure, and respite from your brain. 

When you pick up a brush, pen, or pencil (thread, clay, fabric…), your brain gets a rest and becomes more alive and flexible. The world around you becomes more alive; you pick up on shades, details, and patterns all around you. Your intuition gets stronger. And fear lessens, anxiety fades, and curiosity grows. You stop worrying about making mistakes, and instead, you find the freedom to simply create

description:

Explore the bounty of summer at the Marin Farmers Markets. Taste vine-ripened tomatoes, corn that was picked that morning, and peaches so juicy you have to bend over just to get a bite. Farm-fresh eggs, grass-fed beef, artisan c heeses, raw milk, and freshly baked breads complete the shopping exper ience. Specialty prepared foods and handmade art add to the magic of the market.

Enjoy the intimate feeling of the Thursday Marin Farmers Market, an ideal place to meet for lunch and pick up fresh produce for the weekend. title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.

Sonoma County artist, Tosya Shore, presents Celebrating Women, paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air, a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. \(707\) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    www.upstairsart gallery.net 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

What you’ll do

Deborah Donahower takes you through the fundamentals of working with clay in on the wheel in this 8 week course. Designed for all levels \(beginners and those more experienced\) Deborah thoughtfully explores the tried and true techniques of ceramic work with her students through structured assignments, allowing her students to develop their own creative voice in the process.Students will receive instruction in wheel work, glazing, and finishing pieces. With your 8 week class registration, students receive the opportunity to purchase a studio pass for ½ off during the duration of their class. title: Barbies & Bags Workshop
description:
Schedule

Sunday, February 15, 2026 1:00 PM – 4:00 PM

Location

Room 201, Fiber Arts Studio

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Programming, Sustainability

Age\(s\)

All Ages are welcome to attend Children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult

$25 – One Bag or Doll Entry $40 – Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 – 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we’ll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we’re expanding the exhibit to include bags—think totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It’s a joy to see your art find a new home—and to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

About the Class

Have you always wanted to learn to crochet – or are you ready to build on the skills you already have? Join us in the Fiber Arts Studio for four relaxed Tuesday evening sessions dedicated to learning and practicing crochet. Beginners will start with the essentials: how to hold the hook comfortably, maintain even tension, and work the foundational stitches – chain, single crochet, and double crochet. Students with prior experience are welcome to begin a new project or bring a work-in-progress for guidance and skill-building. All materials are provided for beginners. Returning or experienced crocheters may bring their own supplies or use yarn available in the studio.

title: Encaustic + Mixed Media
description:
Join us at Encaustic Open Studio, a monthly workshop designed for you to refine your encaustic painting skills under the guidance of knowledgeable instructor Susan Heeringa Piper. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced artist, this is the perfect opportunity to immerse yourself in the captivating world of encaustic art.

Encaustic painting is an ancient technique that involves using molten beeswax and pigments to create stunning, textured masterpieces. This unique medium allows for endless possibilities, as it can be layered, carved, scraped, and fused to create mesmerizing effects and depth. From ethereal landscapes to abstract creations, encaustic painting offers a truly immersive and tactile experience. 

Bring your own substrate or project to work on, or start something new!

title: Monthly Men's Circle - 3rd Thursday
location: The Unstruck Drum - Center for Shamanism
description:
This monthly gathering meets every third Thursday of each month. We have the intention of offering a safe space for all men who walk a path of seeking authenticity. Led by Collin Hoctor, this group brings community, shares wisdom, and brings healing to those who desire to walk a deeper, more meaningful life.

From Collin:

I am a psychotherapist and guide whose work weaves together spirituality, nature-based practices, psychedelic therapy, and recovery. My path has been shaped by a foundation in existential philosophy and psychology, medicine circles, and a lifelong study of contemplative and esoteric traditions. Out of my own longing for community and a commitment to the needs of the moment, I am passionate about creating spaces for men to gather in honesty, vulnerability, and authenticity — places where we can face our struggles, share our truths, and remember the healing power of connection.

title: Marty O'Reilly
description:
There’s something about Marty O’Reilly’s music that feels like it’s always been here—like an old story being told in a new way. His voice is raw and real, his guitar playing gritty and soulful. It’s music that doesn’t try to be anything other than honest, and that’s exactly why it hits so hard.

He pulls inspiration from the roots of Americana; his sound references folk greats like Woody Guthrie, blues legends like Howlin’ Wolf,  gospel pioneers like Sister Rosetta Thorpe, and master storytellers like Tom Waits. It’s a sound that captivates and connects audiences, and leaves them wanting more.

His live shows aren’t just concerts—they’re cathartic experiences. One moment it’s soft and haunting, the next it’s wild and electric. The kind that stay with you long after the lights come up.

But it’s not just about the sound. Marty’s songs dig deep into the human experience—loneliness, connection, love, loss. Whether it’s an intimate solo set or a full band show, he makes every audience feel like they’re part of the story.

Over the years, Marty has built a dedicated following through relentless touring and staying true to his craft. He’s shared the stage with artists like Shakey Graves, St. Paul & The Broken Bones, Sarah Jarosz, and Alice O’Donovan and played at festivals like Bottlerock, SXSW, and High Sierra Music Festival, but his focus has always been on making music that means something.

Marty has poured everything into his music—spending years on the road, self-funding his albums, and navigating the ups and downs of life as an independent artist, husband, and father. But through it all, he’s never lost sight of why he started: to make honest music that connects.

If you’re looking for music that feels real, that makes you stop and listen, Marty O’Reilly is someone you need to hear.

title: Samba no Pé - First Class
description:
Get ready to feel the rhythm and energy of Rio de Janeiro! Samba no Pé \(Samba in the Foot\) is the captivating solo style of samba danced in the streets and at Carnival, known for its rapid, intricate footwork and infectious hip movements.

You will learn

The Basic Step: You will master the signature quick-quick-slow rhythm that defines Samba no Pé.

Arm & Hip Styling: You will learn how to add the authentic flair, movement, and energy that makes Brazilian samba so captivating.

Technique & Posture: You will receive tips on proper body alignment to help you dance longer, faster, and more safely.

Rhythm & Musicality: You will learn how to connect your movement directly to the irresistible beat of the bateria \(the samba drum section\).

This class is perfect for anyone looking to connect with the vibrant spirit of Brazil, improve coordination, and get a fantastic workout—all while learning the foundational steps of this iconic dance. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Date & Time: Thursdays @6:30PM – 7:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Forró Dance with Eric and Abigail
description:
Get ready to connect, spin, and glide to the irresistible rhythms of Forró! Originating in the Northeast of Brazil, Forró is a captivating partner dance known for its close embrace, playful steps, and infectious, feel-good music. It is a social dance that will enrich your life, perfect for a night out or a casual gathering.

You Will Learn:

The Basic Step & Close Embrace: You will master the foundational quick-quick-slow rhythm and learn how to comfortably and confidently navigate the essential close-hold connection that defines Forró.

Leading & Following Techniques: Discover the clear, subtle body cues required to effortlessly lead your partner through turns and variations, and how to follow with grace and responsiveness.

Traveling & Stationary Patterns: Learn fundamental steps like the ‘Caminhada’ \(walking step\) and common stationary turns that will allow you to dance on any size floor.

Rhythm & Musicality: Connect your movement to the distinct musical styles of Forró—from the mellow ‘Xote’ to the faster, more energetic ‘Pé-de-Serra.’

This class is perfect for anyone looking to learn a social partner dance, connect with Brazilian culture, and enjoy a vibrant, community atmosphere. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Class Details

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

Date & Time: Thursdays @7:30PM – 8:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

title: Oakmont Meets Imagination - 52 Years of Creativity
description:
This year’s show will feature the work of more than 50 members of the Oakmont Art Association, showcasing a rich and diverse collection of fine art. Visitors can expect to see original works in acrylic, oil, pastel, watercolor, fiber art, and photography, many of which will be available for purchase. The exhibition highlights the wide range of styles, techniques, and personal visions represented by Oakmont’s artists, making each year’s show a fresh and inspiring experience.

In addition to fine art, the show will include a lively Artisan Marketplace. Artisans will offer an array of handcrafted items, including jewelry, photography, assemblage art, fiber and fabric pieces, original books, pottery, fused glass, and many other unique small works. These one-of-a-kind creations make perfect gifts and provide an opportunity to support local artists directly.

The event is designed to be both engaging and festive. Attendees can enjoy live music by Oakmont musicians and appetizers while browsing the exhibits and visiting with artists. A popular highlight of the show is the annual raffle, which adds an extra element of excitement while supporting a meaningful cause. In 2025 more than 50 raffle prizes were generously donated by local businesses.  Raffle drawing and wine reception occurs at 3:30 p.m. Saturday.

Proceeds from the raffle benefit Art Quest, an organization that supports Santa Rosa students who are pursuing education and careers in the arts. The generosity of past attendees has made a real impact—the 2025 raffle raised $3,200 for Art Quest, helping to foster creativity and opportunity for young artists in our region.

The Oakmont Art Association invites the community to attend this special event, celebrate 52 years of creativity, and experience the imagination, skill, and passion of its artists.

title: Painting Flora and Fauna in Watercolor
description:
Schedule

Fridays, March. 20- April 24, 2026 10:00 AM – 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

All Levels

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$275 – Registration Cost $25 – Materials Fee $300 – Total Registration CostIn this six-week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium.

About the Class

In this six-week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium. We will focus on strengthening one’s observational drawing skills, giving the artist a foundation off of which to build their paintings in a step-by-step layering process that trains the artist to see value and color. Our subject matter will be flora and fauna – a sampling of plants and animals. These subjects are great for beginners and experienced artists alike; their organic shapes make them forgiving drawing subjects, but their beauty can be a muse for life.  Instructor Hannah Day is a passionate nature lover and watercolorist and will share her unique approach to rendering botanicals and animal portraits in watercolor. This class will work both from photographs and from life, practicing observational drawing in addition to watercolor technique. With six class sessions, participants will have the opportunity to develop their skills and build muscle memory with a medium that often feels like it has a mind of its own.  This class is open to artists of all skill levels. All materials are provided.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  2/13/26

MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN

EXHIBIT DATES:  February 23 – March 29, 2026

RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.

Sonoma County artist, Tosya Shore, presents Celebrating Women, paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women’s History Month. Shore’s watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.  These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.  A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in “Good Point.”  The artist takes us into nature with “Redwood Rendezvous” where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.    “Just Back from Vegas” captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.  “There’s such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic – women deserve nothing less,” noted Shore. 

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

 The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features Donna Schaffer’s Ooh La La, Plein Air, a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.  Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with “la belle vie.” The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in “Café le Bistro”, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.  One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer’s unique view of the Eiffel Tower in “Paris is for Lovers.” “Every day was an adventure in Paris – I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there”, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. \(707\) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    www.upstairsart gallery.net 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Adult Gymnastics Class
description:
**We’re offering Adult Gymnastics Classes for the 18+ crowd!**

**Adult Gymnastics classes occur every Tuesday 5:00 PM to 6:30 PM & Friday from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM.**

**$20 per person, OR pay for a whole 8-week session in advance through our site. You can attend on Tuesday, Friday, or both!**

**Please bring the class fee in cash at the time of arrival. This can be a DROP IN, so there is no need to sign up online before coming!**

If you’ve ever wanted to try out gymnastics or get back into it in adulthood, now is your chance! During our adult classes, open to all genders, our coaches will move at the pace of each student, helping them achieve goals they set for themselves. **No experience is necessary** to be involved in this class, so this is a great opportunity to learn the basics and get some exercise, no matter what age you are! Try out our trampoline, bars, beam, and other gym equipment in a safe and supportive environment. You can build strength and increase your range of motion while having fun like you’re a kid again.

Ask our coaches what you can work on between classes, and they’ll help personalize your training!

Please wear something comfortable and keep long hair tied back. Skirts and restrictive clothing are not recommended. You must remove your shoes before going onto the mat or using equipment. Please let us know if you have any physical limitations or health conditions that may interfere with doing certain motions. We recommend bringing a water bottle.

You can email us for more info or join our mailing list at: info@sonomagymnasticsacademy.com

title: Online: Resilience & the Open Heart: Somatic Practices for Everyday Stress
description:
with Pawan Bareja, PhD

When we are out of alignment with our deepest heart values, life feels stressful. Whether the trigger is personal heartbreak, economic pressure, relational conflict, or the weight of the climate crisis, the body often reacts with anxiety, collapse, anger, or overwhelm long before the mind can make sense of it. You are invited to move from stress to love by transforming these patterns through embodied heart practices.

Each week, we will begin by gently noticing where activation lives in the body. We’ll then engage in embodied heart-opening practices to soothe the nervous system and reconnect with inner clarity. After practice, we will re-check the nervous system to observe what has shifted, revealing resilience as something softly felt, measurable, and trainable.

As the heart opens and the body softens, many experience deeper rest, clearer thinking, a renewed sense of connection to loved ones, and the courage to live a more meaningful life.

title: A Night with National Geographic Urban Ecologist Dr. Chris Schell
description:
**A Night with National Geographic Urban Ecologist Dr. Chris Schell**

**Friday, March 20**

**EcoLab Theater at CIA Copia, Napa CA**

**Doors: 5:30 PM | Program 6:00 PM**

Think wildlife lives “somewhere else”? Think again. Join National Geographic Explorer Dr. Chris Schell for a mind-expanding journey into the surprising world of urban coyotes, foxes, raccoons — and the hidden histories that shaped the ecosystems right outside our doors.

Dr. Schell’s groundbreaking work uncovers how environmental injustice, resilience, and human choices ripple through entire cities, transforming the animals who live alongside us. You’ll never see a neighborhood stroll the same way again.

A powerful, eye-opening evening for anyone curious about science, justice, and the wild stories unfolding in our own backyard.

**Be curious.  Be surprised.  Be there.**

Their shared past ignites a firestorm of passion, leading them to abandon their new partners and escape together to Paris. This witty and chaotic escape reignites a turbulent romance filled with both adoration and dramatic clashes, as their spurned spouses, Victor and Sibyl, give chase. Discover this sharp, hilarious battle of the sexes, a timeless exploration of love, lust, and the scandalous, intoxicating nature of human relationships. Michael Fontaine, Stage Director

title: Live Music – Anthony Presti
location: Adobe Road Tasting Room, 6 Petaluma Blvd. N - Suite A1 Petaluma, CA
description: Join us for a special Saturday acoustic live music set at Adobe Road Winery in downtown Petaluma. Sip on award-winning wines while enjoying talented local musicians in a warm and inviting atmosphere. Choose from wines by the glass or bottle to discover new favorites. Reserve your spot on Tock and make it a memorable night of great music, fine wine, and good company! About Anthony Presti Singer/Songwriter, Anthony Presti, grew up in Seattle in the 90’s during a thriving grunge movement, obsessing over bands like Nirvana and Pearl Jam while being exposed to bands like the Grateful Dead and Jethro Tull by his uncles, who taught him the significance of music. He ended up moving to Sonoma County as a teenager, where punk dominated the mainstream. After playing in a hardcore band for a number of years, Presti discovered an affinity for acoustic guitar and folk songwriting and eventually settled in San Francisco where he formed his backing band, The Tusslers. Presti’s style encompasses folk nuances mixed with the inspirations of his rock upbringing. He’s released two full length albums, including his second record in 2017, Existentialism, recorded at John Vanderslice’s Tiny Telephone Studios and is currently working on his latest release due out this year, Different Places, at Hyde Street Studios.

title: Olompali State Historic Park - Exploratory Hike
description:
Mindfull Hikes
***Please be in good enough shape to hike at a moderate/fast steady pace (+/-2.5 mph) and comfortable with elevation changes.***

The park overlooks the Petaluma River and San Pablo Bay from the east-facing slopes of 1,558 foot Mount Burdell. The name "olompali" comes from the Miwok language and may be translated as "southern village" or "southern people." The Coast Miwok inhabited at least one site within the area of the present-day park continuously from as early as 6,000 BC, until the early 1850s.

**Distance:** +/- 9 miles total; out and back

**The hike:**
Exploratory because I've not led this hike and it has been many years since I hiked it. We'll start off on the Miwok Trail to Burdell Trail to the turn around point. At the peak of Mt Burdell we'll head back the way we came on Burdell Trail and then talke the Miwok loop trail to the starting place.

**Where to meet:** Parking lot of the park

**Directions:**
The park is accessible from both the Northbound and Southbound lanes of Highway 101. Exit at Atherton Ave./San Marin Dr. and follow posted directional signs to the park.

*Please be on time. We’ll start promptly at the start time listed.* ***Give yourself a little extra time to arrive*** and get situated so that you’re part of the opening circle as this is an essential part of our time together.

**Parking:**
Free if you have a CA State Park pass.
OR $10, payable by cash, check, or via smartphone with QR code at the parking lot. If paying by cash, look for the yellow fee payment tube at the west end of the parking lot to deposit your payment.

**Restroom**: Near the parking area

**What to bring:** Lunch, water, hat, good hiking shoes, a joyful spirit and laughter. Please dress appropriately for the weather that day. Layers of clothing are always advisable.
**===================================**
**Reminders:**
Mindful hikes are intended to be a way to connect more fully with ourselves, each other and with the land. There will be two periods of silent walking throughout the hike to allow the senses to be fully alive and felt. There will also be time during the hike to visit and connect with each other. These times of talking and connecting are an invitation to bring mindfulness to the present moment. **It's a time to put away the cell phone and cameras to disengage from technology to be fully present with each other, our *senses and the land we are inhabiting.***

***If you're on the waitlist for the hike and want to attend please message Vickie a few days before the scheduled hike. Most hikes have people drop off at the last minute and it's possible there is an opening.***

**Dāna**
In the spirit of the Buddhist tradition mindful hikes are offered as a dāna based event. Rick Hansen says “generosity is a beautiful practice that opens and gladdens the heart, relaxes the contraction of ‘self’ and ripples out into the world to touch many people.” The dāna practice is **heart centered** and in the spirit of generosity. Venmo or cash is graciously accepted. Venmo account is: @vickieix8; last four digits 4714 of my phone # if asked.

**No-Show Policy:** Please cancel at least 24 hours before the start of the hike. Be mindful that there may be a waitlist. If your plans change and you're not coming, opening up a spot 4-5 days before the hike it's more likely someone will be able to attend than if you cancel at the last minute. You're considered a no-show if you cancel at the last minute. Members with 2 no-shows are removed from the group.

title: The Crooked Stuff
location: The Big Easy, 128 American Alley, Petaluma, CA, 94952, United States
description:
Existential discopunk for the people! The Crooked Stuff transmits a hybrid, body-moving, synthesizer-driven sound that’s been cross-pollinated and grown at the sonic crossroads of ’70s funk, ’80s punk and new wave, ’90s alternative, and ’00s electronic dance music. At the core, the music is fueled by a blend of introspective searching and life-affirming extroverted blasts that aim to shock audiences into their own inspired moments of living forward and free. 
Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the trio (vocals, synths & drums) was born from the unique mash-up of founding members Tom G. (vocals) and John Varn (synths) and their diverse musical backgrounds. Tom’s roots trace back to the Washington, D.C., hardcore punk and new wave scene, which was also intertwined with the district’s heavy go-go and soul sounds. Varn grew up in the Bay Area music scene, surrounded by and mentored by its legendary psychedelic rock and funk players. Together, the two have created a full-spectrum sound experience that continually morphs and blends their wide-ranging influences and polar-opposite backgrounds. 
Fans say The Crooked Stuff’s complex sonic formula consistently delivers an undeniable, energizing live-show reaction. One called it “like INXS injected into The Prodigy.” Another said, “It’s somewhere between Gorillaz, Daft Punk, and TV on the Radio.” Someone else described it as “Johnny Rotten hijacking LCD Soundsystem and throwing Herbie Hancock on synths.” All agreed—they were feeling it! 
The Crooked Stuff… arise, release, be free! 
Web: www.TheCrookedStuff.com
IG: www.Instagram.com/TheCrookedStuff
FB: www.Facebook.com/TheCrookedStuff 
Apple Music: https://apple.co/2Ldy0sF
Spotify: http://bit.ly/The-Crooked-Stuff

title: English Country Dance Napa
description:
North Bay Contra Dance
English country dancing is done in long lines (like contra), circles, or in geometric sets (squares, triangles). Like our contra dances, there is live music and a caller. You can come by yourself or with friends, since we change partners after each dance. If you’ve ever done contra or square dancing, much of our dance vocabulary will be familiar to you since both of those styles evolved from English country dancing.

The dance is held the 1st and 3rd Sundays of each month, 2-4:30 pm, to live music, all levels of experience welcome; and occasional 5th Sundays for Advanced dancers. Admission is $15 for members of NBCDS and its affiliates, $8 for young adults ages 19-30, and $3 for youth ages 6 – 18.

title: Tuesday Night Fitness Hike: 5+ Fast Miles, Downtown Petaluma and Western Hills
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
WARNING: THE TUESDAY NIGHT FITNESS HIKE IS AN AEROBIC, FAST-PACED URBAN HIKE! WE TARGET A PACE OF 16-MINUTES PER MILE WITH ONLY BRIEF STOPS (TO REGROUP AS NEEDED). OUR SUMMER ROUTE INCLUDES THE HILLS IN HELEN PUTNAM PARK (740 FT. ELEVATION GAIN), AND OUR WINTER ROUTE EXPLORES THE WATER TANKS (690 FT. ELEVATION GAIN). IF YOU FIND YOU ARE HAVING DIFFICULTY KEEPING UP WITH THE LEADERS IN THIS GROUP, PLEASE USE THE OPT-OUT POINT AT THE FIRST MILE OF THE HIKE! ANOTHER OPTION IS OUR WEDNESDAY NIGHT WALK FOR A MORE MODERATE PACE. THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME KEEP THIS HIKE AN AEROBIC WORKOUT!

NOTE:
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is posted on the SCO Calendar every week. Steve Tubbs is shown as the host each week but he might, or might not, show up to the event. This is, more often than not, a small group of regular, fit walkers who show up on time every Tuesday night to enjoy this rigorous walk. We leave promptly at 6:10 pm from the Kentucky Street entrance to the LanMart Building. So, if you don't see Steve on the Tuesday night you are there, you might see him on the next one.

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike, 5+ miles fast paced urban hike:

This Fitness Hike includes multiple steep uphill portions in Helen Putnam Park (during Daylight Savings Time), and at the Petaluma Water Tanks (after Daylight Savings Time ends).

Tuesday Night Fitness Hike:

* Warning! This is a FAST hike... a real workout!
* 5+ miles
* Meetup time 6:00 pm (We hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Difficulty is STRENUOUS!
* 90 minutes

This is a fast, evening Fitness Hike that starts downtown outside (on the sidewalk) of the LanMart Building (Brixx Restaurant, Heebe Jeebe) on Kentucky Street. We head west to Helen Putnam Park (or the Petaluma Water Tanks when DST ends) for some beautiful vistas before returning to our starting point on Kentucky Street. This hike is generally the same route and is focused primarily on fitness.

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking/hiking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

WHAT ABOUT THE DARKNESS?
Bring a SMALL flashlight. The sidewalks can be treacherous in west Petaluma, and you'll want to see those crags, cracks and upheavals in the concrete. Reflective clothing is also recommended so that vehicles can see you!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 mph (22 - 23 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike nearly 3.5 - 4.0 mph (we target a 16 minute mile, with multiple hills!)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?

Please take the time to RSVP YES when you plan on attending an event. It is equally important to keep your RSVP up to date. If you've RSVP'd YES for an event, we are going to wait for you until the departure time. We leave promptly at 6:10 PM, so if you arrive late you can join us along the route. We typically hike the same route for each hike, and our focus is on aerobic exercise.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

SCO Organizers

title: Happy Hour Crafts
description:
The Rebel Craft Collective
Wine + tasty snacks + your latest project and a friendly group of likeminded crafters... what better way to unwind? Come join us!

This is a relaxed, drop-in-friendly event. Come when you can, leave when you must. Newcomers and occasional-comers are always welcome!

**What do we mean by “crafts”?**
Whatever “craft” means to you! And whatever is portable enough to bring to a wine bar. Knitting, crochet, and other fiber arts are most common, but we have also warmly welcomed people who sketch, color, embroider, bead, and more. If your craft isn’t portable, we will happily ooh and aah over photos of your work-in-progress, or chat about your plans for your next project.

**Health & Safety**
Masks are very welcome, and nobody will pressure you to eat or drink. If the weather is nice, we will try to sit outside. If you aren’t eating/drinking during the event, please consider ordering some of La Dolce Vita’s delicious food to-go, in order to help support our gracious, long-time venue.

**Parking**
Parking in downtown Petaluma is free, but street parking has a strictly enforced 2 hour limit until 6pm. To park for longer, try the nearest garage:

* The Second Street Garage entrance is located on C Street between First and Second Streets. It's all day parking on every level and a short walk to La Dolce Vita.

**Ages**
It's a wine bar, so this event is for adult crafters (though you're certainly not required to drink wine!). We’re okay with babes-in-arms if you are, but this is not the right setting for wee crafters who are moving about on their own.

title: Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown & Riverfront
description:
"SONOMA COUNTY OUTDOORS"
Wednesday Night Walk: Petaluma Downtown and Riverfront

* Want to walk for fitness and exercise?
* New to walking and want to build up stamina?
* Like a slower pace than our Tuesday Night Fitness Hike?
* Would walking with a committed group of walkers help you?

If you said yes to any of these, then the Wednesday Night Walk in Petaluma is for you. We start at Aqus Cafe and take in the West Side of town, including some of Downtown, the Waterfront and a few of the Historic home of old Petaluma. We walk about 3-1/2 to 4-1/2 miles depending on weather conditions and the pace of the group that night.

Afterward if you have the time, join us at Aqus Cafe for a bite to eat and some liquid refreshment before heading home. Aqus Cafe is a true gem of a gathering place, restaurant, coffee house, and live music venue. But it's the people on either side of the counter that make this place so special.

DETAILS:

* Meetup time: 6:00pm (we hike at 6:10 sharp)
* Meetup location: Aqus Cafe
* Distance: 3.5 to 4-1/2 miles
* Duration: 75-80 minutes
* Pace: Easy/Moderate (about 2.5-3 mph or 20-24 minute miles)
* Difficulty: Easy (if you've walked 3-4 miles recently)
* Hills: Mostly flat with a few small and easy to climb hills
* Optional After-Hike Gathering at Aqus Cafe

WHAT TO BRING:

* A good pair of walking shoes
* Water (you'll be glad you did)
* A fun attitude!

SO HOW FAST ARE WE WALKING?
The Wednesday Night Walk is about 2.5 - 3 mph (20-24 minute miles)
The Tuesday Night Fitness Hike is about 3.5-4 mph (15-17 minute miles)

HOW DO YOU PARTICIPATE?
Sign up with Meetup and RSVP Today! This also gets you on our email list to make you aware of upcoming events, hikes and walks. You will not be spammed. If you are, let me know. Spamming will not be tolerated.

WHY DO YOU NEED TO RSVP?
It's important to RSVP for these walks. When all the people have arrived for a walk that have RSVP'd, we leave... it might mean we leave early. If you didn't RSVP we are not going to wait for you. Plus, it's just a nice courtesy to the organizer and other participants. Please take the time to RSVP.

QUESTIONS?
Email me with any questions by using the "Contact Us" link on the left hand side bar of this meetup group page.

Hope to see you on a walk or hike soon!

Gary
SCO Organizer

title: Free Estate Planning Webinar
description: Details Strategies to Manage Incapacity, Family Dynamics, and Financial Risks Creating your estate plan, whether it’s a living trust or a will, can be a daunting task. Estate planning addresses issues that are difficult to think about, such as death, incapacity, finances, and family dynamics. It can be easy to procrastinate, even though these issues may weigh heavily on your mind. We invite you to attend one of our upcoming free webinars so you can take the first step toward having peace of mind by creating (or updating) your estate plan. This is an educational webinar, where we highlight some of the concerns that many families face and how an estate plan can help. The attorneys also break down how wills and trusts differ, and some of the common estate planning pitfalls and how to avoid them. Our goal is to provide you with the education you need to protect yourself and your family, and leave a legacy of peace. If you would like to set up a meeting to discuss your estate planning needs

title: Lake Sonoma Hike
description:
Mindfull Hikes
***Please be in good enough shape to hike at a moderate/fast steady pace (+/-2.5 mph) and comfortable with elevation changes.***

**Distance:** +/- 5 miles total
**The hike:** We'll hike through a magical madrone forest, take in beautiful expansive views of the Mayacama Mountain range as well as the Dry Creek and Warm Springs arms of Lake Sonoma. A loop hike - Dry Creek, Half a Canoe Loop, North Slope and Bummer trails.

**Parking:** National Parks pass OR $7; day pass can be purchased on-site using a credit card through the Recreation.gov mobile app. Once on-site, follow the posted Scan & Pay instructions. You will need to download the free Recreation.gov mobile app prior to your arrival as some remote areas have limited or no cellular service. For more information about paying on-site, click here: https://help.r1s-test.com/helpcenter?id=kb_article&sys_id=2011ea4a1b84bcd076c1dbdbe54bcb1d

**Where to Meet:** Little Flat Parking (A large gravel parking lot)
From Hwy 101 take Dry Creek Road west towards Lake Sonoma. Go up the hill and across the bridge over the lake. Pay Attention, it's the first right turn into "Little Flat" parking lot.

https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lake+Sonoma+Little+Flat+Trailhead/@38.7154999,-123.0249632,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m6!3m5!1s0x808403d82665bd79:0x90dfb0e61fe4d074!8m2!3d38.7154999!4d-123.0223883!16s%2Fg%2F11f5g02g3q?entry=ttu&g_ep=EgoyMDI1MDIxMi4wIKXMDSoASAFQAw%3D%3D

*Please be on time. We’ll start promptly at the start time listed.* Give yourself a little extra time to arrive and get situated so that you’re part of the opening circle as this is an essential part of our time together.

**Restroom:** None

**What to bring:** Snack, water, hat, good hiking shoes, a joyful spirit and laughter. Please dress appropriately for the weather that day. Layers of clothing are always advisable.
**===================================**
**Reminders:**
Mindful hikes are intended to be a way to connect more fully with ourselves, each other and with the land. There will be two periods of silent walking throughout the hike to allow the senses to be fully alive and felt. There will also be time during the hike to visit and connect with each other. These times of talking and connecting are an invitation to bring mindfulness to the present moment. **It's a time to put away the cell phone and cameras to disengage from technology to be fully present with each other, our *senses and the land we are inhabiting.***

***If you're on the waitlist for the hike and want to attend please message Vickie a few days before the scheduled hike. Most hikes have people drop off at the last minute and it's possible there is an opening.***

**Dāna**
In the spirit of the Buddhist tradition mindful hikes are offered as a dāna based event. Rick Hansen says “generosity is a beautiful practice that opens and gladdens the heart, relaxes the contraction of ‘self’ and ripples out into the world to touch many people.” The dāna practice is **heart centered** and in the spirit of generosity. Venmo or cash is graciously accepted. Venmo account is: @vickieix8; last four digits 4714 of my phone # if asked.

**No-Show Policy:** Please cancel at least 24 hours before the start of the hike. Be mindful that there may be a waitlist. If your plans change and you're not coming, opening up a spot 4-5 days before the hike it's more likely someone will be able to attend than if you cancel at the last minute. You're considered a no-show if you cancel at the last minute. Members with 2 no-shows are removed from the group.

title: English Country Dance Sebastopol Advanced
description:
North Bay Contra Dance
Our 5th Sunday series is for experienced dancers, so instruction will be streamlined and the dances will be more complex than at our 1st and 3rd Sunday dances. We expect dancers attending these sessions to be completely comfortable with heys for 3 and 4, dolphin heys, figure 8s, and triple minor progression. They should also be able to maintain their sense of orientation within the set. This is not the time to bring your friends who are new to English country dancing, though we’d love to see them at the 1st and 3rd Sundays.

The regular EC dance is held the 1st and 3rd Sundays of each month, 2-4:30 pm, to live music, all levels of experience welcome; and occasional 5th Sundays for Advanced dancers. Admission is $15 for members of NBCDS and its affiliates, $8 for young adults ages 19-30, and $3 for youth ages 6 – 18.
